webTitle: Graphene producer's shares jump by 40% in market debut

fields.standfirst: Shareholders pile in to buy a slice of Applied Graphene Materials, which has found a way to mass produce graphene
fields.body:
A British firm which has found a way to produce industrial quantities of graphene, the wonder material expected to revolutionise the fields of medicine and manufacturing, saw its share price rise 40% during its stock market debut on Wednesday.

Shareholders piled in to buy a slice of Applied Graphene Materials (AGM), which is based in Cleveland and was spun out of Durham University, in a float that was more than two times oversubscribed.

Graphene, a substance isolated by Nobel prize-winning scientists at the University of Manchester in 2004, is a one-molecule-thick layer of graphite that is 20 times stronger than diamond and conducts electricity 20 times better than copper. It has already been used in tennis rackets and future applications range from aircraft bodies to membranes used in DNA sequencing.

Graphene is difficult to make in large quantities, but AGM, which raised £11m by selling a 42% stake, has found a way to mass produce the material in powder and is working with companies including Dyson and Procter & Gamble to develop commercial uses for the material.

"This funding will allow us to begin the next phase of development and to strengthen relationships with our partners," said chief executive John Mabbitt. "Applied Graphene Materials is now well positioned to meet the growing global appetite for graphene as a wonder material of the 21st century."

The float on London's Aim market for smaller companies saw shares pop from the initial placing price of 155p to 216p by the close of the first day's trading, valuing the company at £36m. AGM is forecast to become profitable in 2017.

Founder and technical director Karl Coleman, professor of inorganic chemistry at Durham University, retains a 10% stake, having reduced his holding from 24% before the float. Early backer IP Group, which invests in patent-based businesses, has reinvested and retains a 20% stake.

AGM will use the capital raised on Aim to expand the capacity of its Teesside production facility from one tonne a year to eight over the next 18 months. The company's 10-strong workforce will also increase, with engineers and scientists recruited to develop commercial applications for its products.

Most graphene production relies on natural supplies of graphite, which has to be mined, but AGM has found a way to produce it using carbon atoms sourced from ethanol. Its product can then added to resins, plastics, oils and lubricants.

Dyson wants to use graphene in the plastic casing for its vacuum cleaners, because of its strength, and because its ability to conduct electricity reduces static, which in turn helps the machine suck in more dust.

Added to paints, graphene could help protect the hulls of boats from rust and, as a dry lubricant, reduce drag as the ship moves through water.

While the UK pioneered the discovery of graphene, Asian companies have made the greatest efforts to commercialise it, with electronics giant Samsung leading the way.

"We [the British] are good with the initial materials, but other people are better at seeing applications ... We have to be careful with graphene, otherwise it is one of those things that we just let go," said Mabbitt.

webTitle: JP Morgan's long road to clean-up: time for bank to show what it's really made of | Heidi Moore

fields.standfirst: A $13bn fine and an admission of remorse should be the end of the affair – but JP Morgan and the rest of Wall St have more to do
fields.body:
In politics, there's a saying about what gets you in hot water: it’s not the crime; it’s the cover-up. In the financial industry you might say: it’s not the crime; it’s the clean-up.

The clean-up period – the financial and moral reckoning that can last up to a decade – is when you get to see what a bank and its culture are made of: whether they respond with remorse (rare), with distancing hubris (frequent), or with lavish payouts (always).

JP Morgan just paid a $13bn fine to settle charges that it sold bad mortgages to investors and government agencies. The bank didn’t admit to breaking the law, but it agreed it misrepresented the quality of mortgage securities that it sold. Such an admission and such a large fine, being the biggest in US corporate history, would seem to draw a line under the whole sordid mortgage affair – but, as events of the past week have shown, the bank’s clean-up is really just beginning.

There are, inevitably, more fines and lawsuits to come this year. Harry Fong, a managing director with Wall Street research firm MKM Partners, suggested that the settlement might prove good news for others waiting to sue JP Morgan as well as its rivals: “The headlines of the settlement certainly seem to favor counterparties still in litigation against JPM and other banks,” he wrote, though he also cautioned that the courts may not be sufficiently moved: “But headlines are not judicial rulings.”

It will all come at a cost. JP Morgan recently announced its first loss since 2004 due to legal costs, and Barclays analyst Jason Goldberg estimates that the bank’s remaining $23bn reserve for legal costs will cover potential lawsuits that are yet to be settled. Goldberg suggests that even with the money JP Morgan has already set aside, there’s still $13bn in its vaults to cover potential litigation.

Still, there is no small number of people waiting to get satisfaction from JP Morgan. The banks faces class-action lawsuits and legal actions by insurance companies and investors disputing insurance on mortgage loans.

In addition, as Goldberg point out, there’s a litany of other troubles waiting in the wings, some in their early stages and some close to wrapping up: federal regulators are still investigating some of JP Morgan’s employees about the London Whale losses; the FBI and the Department of Justice are trying to figure out if JP Morgan did enough to alert investors about the Bernie Madoff fraud; and there are other government investigations around money-laundering, debt collection, a criminal investigation by the Department of Justice around energy-market manipulation, potential issues around hiring children of Chinese officials; and a brewing multi-bank investigation in currency markets.

Then there is the reputational clean-up, which is much harder than paying a fine. Last week, there was a debacle in which JP Morgan welcomed career questions for one of its top bankers by asking Twitter users to send queries with the #AskJPM hashtag. It backfired, as users hurled abuse at the bank: “When can I get my house back?” wrote one wag. Another wit suggested that the bank could advise him whether he was fully diversified … in financial malfeasance.

Many people attributed the #askJPM catastrophe to JP Morgan’s misunderstanding of social media. It was not. It was a misunderstanding of the depth of public outrage against the bank and the depths to which its reputation had fallen since the financial crisis. For a few hours, JP Morgan was in the stocks, and you could tell that there was a public hunger for more mockery, if not outright punishment.

Will any of this affect the tenure of the bank’s charismatic chief executive, James Dimon? Probably not. Goldberg believes Dimon’s job is secure – “we expect Dimon to remain CEO for the foreseeable future” – and so do many others.

There are a few reasons for this. The most compelling is incumbency: if all this – the London Whale, the enormous settlements – couldn’t shake Dimon’s control, what will?

There’s also a widespread belief that the pool of people able to lead a financial behemoth is small to non-existent, and the long and painful searches in the past for CEOs at Citigroup and Bank of America support that view.

In addition, Dimon has the support of his board, who may recognize that their support of him in the past means their fortunes are tied to his. One board member said earlier this year that “we’ve got these things that we actually are guilty of and we’ve got to fix them.”

That level of self-awareness was considered a rare break from form – and even a faux pas – for JP Morgan. But what it did was acknowledge the truth. The entire financial industry could use more of that. Until it does, there will be no end to the true costs of the clean-up.

webTitle: Lloyds boss to receive £2.3m bonus in 2018

fields.standfirst: António Horta-Osório has to wait five years before cashing in shares he is receiving under an incentive scheme
fields.body:
The boss of Lloyds Banking Group has been awarded a £2.3m bonus.

But António Horta-Osório, the Portuguese banker who has been at the helm of the bailed-out bank for two and a half years, will have to wait five years before he can cash in the shares he is receiving under the terms of a scheme put in place in March.

He stood to receive just over 3m shares if the share price remained above 73.6p for 30 days – the price at which the taxpayer breaks even on its 42% stake in the bank. After the shares closed at 75.02p on Wednesday, those terms had been met. The shares have risen from the levels closer to 50p when the chief executive's bonus was first tied to the share-price performance.

Horta-Osório had asked for the payout to be linked to the share price to show the returns being generated for taxpayers, while the Treasury had stipulated that he could receive the shares if the government had sold off at least a third of its holding at prices above 61p.

The bank is facing a dispute with unions over changes to pensions that limit rises to members of the final salary scheme. Ged Nichols, general secretary of the Accord union, said: "We think it is right that the Lloyds Banking Group fulfils its promises to its employees if the employees have done what the organisation asked of them in return. We hope the bank will act with the same integrity to the loyal, hard-working and sometimes low-paid employees who have also made their contribution to the bank's recovery by honouring its pensions promises to these employees."

When the potential bonus was first announced it was worth £1.4m, but because of the rise in the share price it is now worth £2.3m – and will continue to fluctuate in value until Horta-Osório is able to cash in the shares, not before 2018.

The bank said: "António's bonus, which he won't receive until 2018, reflects the significant turnaround at Lloyds under his leadership – something that has enabled taxpayers to start getting back their money at a profit."

The Treasury has started to sell down its stake in Lloyds, selling 15% of its holding in September at 75p a share – bringing in a small profit for the taxpayer on the sale and used by the government to cut the national debt by £586m.

webTitle: BSkyB 'keen' to cut sports wholesale deal with BT

fields.bodyText: BSkyB would be "keen" to cut a sports wholesale deal with BT, chief executive Jeremy Darroch said in his first public comments since the telecoms company's £900m swoop on broadcast rights for Champions League football. "It has to be a two way thing, so we'd want reciprocity in terms of supply," Darroch said on Wednesday. "So if we can get there with BT, my position has always been very open to do that." Sky's share price fell 11% last week after it lost the rights it had shared with ITV to the Europa League soccer games, as investors reacted to the most serious challenge yet to Sky's dominance of sports broadcasting. Speaking in Barcelona at a conference organised by Morgan Stanley bank, Darroch reiterated his conditions for doing a deal with BT. Sky has withheld its premium sports channels from hundreds of thousands of viewers who have installed BT's new YouView box. Darroch is prepared to do a wholesale deal, allowing BT to sell Sky Sports 1 and 2 on YouView – but only if it is allowed to sell the BT Sports channels to its own satellite customers. BT Sports is available on satellite, but not via a Sky package – customers must sign up directly with BT. The telecoms group has signed more than 2m customers to its sports channels, with a further 2m Virgin Media homes receiving them automatically as part of their TV bundle. Darroch said Champions League accounted for less than 3% of viewing on Sky while cricket, tennis, Formula 1 and golf tournaments, as well as the Premier League, were a big part of its offer. "There is a point at which the price that's paid is worth more than it is to our business and frankly that was the case with Champions League," said Darroch. Sky would be in good shape, he said, for the crucial auction for the next set of Premier League rights, which is expected at the end of 2014 or early in 2015. But Darroch sought to downplay the potential impact of BT's assault on sports, saying Sky now offered much more than football, and that it was now second only to BT in offering home broadband and phone services. "While sports is important within Sky it's just one of the things we do. Our entertainment channels are working very well including our own investments in production and commissioning." A spokeswoman for BT said: "We have always said we will wholesale BT Sport where it makes commercial sense for both parties. BT has always been open to reaching a commercial deal with Sky but they have resisted this to date."

webTitle: Former Co-op Bank chairman boasted of links to political parties

fields.standfirst: Paul Flowers told MPs of meetings with Tory minister Owen Paterson and shadow chancellor Ed Balls
fields.body:
Paul Flowers, the former chairman of the Co-operative Bank, boasted of links to the major political parties in his recent appearance before the Treasury select committee.

He described how he had met the former Northern Ireland minister Owen Paterson at the Conservative party conference after the May 2010 election and said the Conservative MP Mark Hoban had been involved in discussions with the bank over its now aborted attempt to buy more than 600 branches from Lloyds Banking Group.

In his evidence, Flowers was also asked about a £50,000 donation from the wider Co-operative Group to the shadow chancellor, Ed Balls – whom he said he had met at Labour party conference functions. Flowers's Labour party membership has been suspended since the publication on Sunday of a video allegedly showing him handing over cash for illegal drugs.

The meeting with Paterson was at the Hyatt hotel at the Conservative party conference in 2010, Flowers said, when he was asked if the Co-op would help rescue the troubled Belfast Presbyterian Mutual Society.

Paterson was then the minister for Northern Ireland. "I was invited to meetings with the then secretary of state, Mr Paterson, his junior minister and his most senior civil servant. That meeting occurred in his bedroom at the Hyatt hotel at the Conservative party conference in 2010," Flowers said.

He was asked by MPs whether the Co-op bank was put under political pressure to buy the 631 branches from Lloyds. The talks collapsed this year just before the scale of the bank's £1.5bn capital shortfall was announced.

Flowers, who was chairman of the bank from March 2010 until June this year, said Hoban had "many, many telephone conversations" with the then chief executive of the Co-op Group, Peter Marks. When Marks, who left the Co-op Group in May, gave evidence to the committee he did not make any reference to any political contact.

"It would be fair to say that we also had nods of support from Vince Cable, who was and still is secretary of state for business," Flowers said.

He did not claim to have had personal meetings with either Hoban or Cable about the long-running negotiations to buy the branches from Lloyds.

But the deal collapsed in April after more than a year of discussions, dashing the coalition's hopes of creating an enlarged bank big enough to challenge the major players on the high street. At the time, the Co-op had said it was "not in the best interests" of its 7 milllion members, who in effect own the group, because of a worsening outlook for the economy.

A month later the bank's credit was downgraded to junk by the ratings agency Moody's. In June – just after Flowers had left – the £1.5bn capital shortfall was announced.

The bank is now racing to fill that hole, giving up control to a group of bondholders, led by two US hedge funds, which will end up owning 70% – provided they vote on the terms of the intricate transaction by the end of the month.

Flowers was also asked about loans by the Co-op Bank to the Labour party but insisted those were "done commercially by executives and never by the board".

webTitle: Ikea France executives under investigation amid spying accusations

fields.standfirst: Head of Ikea France among those accused of employing private detectives to snoop on employees, particularly union activists, and even unhappy clients
fields.body:
Three senior Ikea executives in France were put under investigation on Wednesday over allegations they spied on disgruntled customers and former staff.

The head of Ikea France is among those accused of employing a firm of private detectives to snoop on individual employees, particularly union activists, job applicants and even unhappy customers, and of fraudulently obtaining personal information from police files.

A judge decided there was enough evidence to formally mis en examen (the equivalent of being charged) Stefan Vanoverbeke, the chief executive of Ikea France, his predecessor Jean-Louis Baillo and chief financial officer Dariusz Rychert, who were arrested on Monday and held for questioning.

Under French law, the men had to be formally put under investigation within 24 hours or freed.

Since January, a total of 10 people have been arrested and put under investigation for "fraudulent use of personal information", including four police officers and Ikea's former head of security.

The case is hugely damaging to the reputation of the flagship Swedish company famed for its family-friendly but infuriatingly difficult to assemble flat-pack furniture.

The accused are said to have requested a range of personal data, including criminal records and confidential details about the targets' dealings with the police or courts, even as witnesses or victims. Scores of people were alleged to have been snooped on, including a union official.

Last year, the satirical magazine Le Canard Enchainé obtained and published emails allegedly between Ikea's management in France and Sûreté International suggesting the security company was obtaining information from the national police information system on behalf of Ikea. The magazine said Ikea agreed to pay Sûreté International €80 (£66) for each request for information and that up to 200 demands were made at the same time.

Two unions have filed legal complaints against Ikea, accusing it of snooping on hundreds of people over a period of at least five years.

Among the claims is that Ikea asked investigators to find out if a customer, who was suing the company for €4,000 (£3,350), owned her own property or was known to the police. Other accusations centre on the tracing of car registration numbers.

Vanoverbek's lawyer, Alexis Gulbin, said his client denied involvement. "It was he who took corrective measures as soon as the problems were detected," Gulbin said.

Ikea France suspended and later fired the head of its risk management department last year along with three top-level executives, before publishing a new code of conduct.

In a statement in 2012, Christophe Naudin, head of Sûreté International, told journalists last year it had "consultancy and security contracts" with Ikea, but flatly denied snooping for the firm.

If found guilty of fraudulently using personal information, the accused face up to five years in prison and €300,000 in fines.
fields.bodyText: Three senior Ikea executives in France were put under investigation on Wednesday over allegations they spied on disgruntled customers and former staff. The head of Ikea France is among those accused of employing a firm of private detectives to snoop on individual employees, particularly union activists, job applicants and even unhappy customers, and of fraudulently obtaining personal information from police files. A judge decided there was enough evidence to formally mis en examen (the equivalent of being charged) Stefan Vanoverbeke, the chief executive of Ikea France, his predecessor Jean-Louis Baillo and chief financial officer Dariusz Rychert, who were arrested on Monday and held for questioning. Under French law, the men had to be formally put under investigation within 24 hours or freed. Since January, a total of 10 people have been arrested and put under investigation for "fraudulent use of personal information", including four police officers and Ikea's former head of security. The case is hugely damaging to the reputation of the flagship Swedish company famed for its family-friendly but infuriatingly difficult to assemble flat-pack furniture. The accused are said to have requested a range of personal data, including criminal records and confidential details about the targets' dealings with the police or courts, even as witnesses or victims. Scores of people were alleged to have been snooped on, including a union official. Last year, the satirical magazine Le Canard Enchainé obtained and published emails allegedly between Ikea's management in France and Sûreté International suggesting the security company was obtaining information from the national police information system on behalf of Ikea. The magazine said Ikea agreed to pay Sûreté International €80 (£66) for each request for information and that up to 200 demands were made at the same time. Two unions have filed legal complaints against Ikea, accusing it of snooping on hundreds of people over a period of at least five years. webTitle: Royal Mail bankers accused of botching privatisation and costing taxpayers - as it happened

fields.standfirst:
• Committee chair: Don't give bankers more fees
• Bankers grilled - a round-up of the key points
• VOTE: Should Goldman and UBS get £4m payment?
• Brian Binley MP: Bankers messed up - 'anyone can sell cheap beer'
fields.body:
7.24pm GMT

The last post

Time to wrap up here, as postal workers around the UK crack on with processing tonight's mail for the morning.

Our news story on today's hearing, just launched, is here:

Royal Mail float: paying bankers' deferred fees would be 'mad', MP says

Highlights of today's session at the BIS committee start here.

My summary of the key points is here.

There's reaction here, and again here.

You can still vote in our poll on whether Goldman Sachs and UBS should get their outstanding payment for their work on the Mail sale.

And here's a few questions which Vince Cable might like to ponder.

We'll be back tomorrow, with more general coverage of events - having rather gone postal today. Cheers, and goodnight. GW.

7.14pm GMT

Bailey: Goldman and UBS shouldn't get £4m deferred fees

Some late news: Adrian Bailey, the chair of the BIS committee, has told the Guardian that the government would be "mad" to pay Goldman Sachs and UBS the outstanding £4m fees they could receive for their work on Royal Mail.

My colleague Sean Farrell has the story.

The government would be "mad" to pay more than £4m of deferred fees to the banks that advised on Royal Mail's privatisation because they undervalued the company, the chairman of a powerful parliamentary committee said after grilling the bankers on Wednesday.

Adrian Bailey, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) Select Committee, said paying the fees, on top of more than £12m already handed over, would reward highly paid bankers who set the float price too low at the expense of the taxpayer.

Bailey gave his judgment after the committee had quizzed senior bankers from Goldman Sachs and UBS, the banks that led the flotation. In more than two hours of questioning they were accused of failing at their jobs and selling the taxpayer short.

The government sold 60% of Royal Mail at 330p a share last month, valuing the company at £3.3bn. But the shares leapt 38% on their first day of trading and closed tonight at 550p, giving Royal Mail a market value of £5.5bn.

Goldman, UBS and five other banks that marketed the shares have so far been paid £12.7m between them but they could get another £4.2m if Vince Cable, the secretary of state, thinks they warrant it.

Bailey said: "The government, in view of what has happened subsequently, would be mad to give them [the money].

"It would be seen as rewarding the private sector that lost the tax payer potentially £1bn and in these days of austerity I think it would be a very politically dangerous thing to do. These are professional people, who got it wrong, and they would be rewarded despite the fact they got it wrong."

Here's the full story: Royal Mail float: paying bankers' deferred fees would be 'mad', MP says

6.48pm GMT

On the inquiry into the Co-op Bank scandal, my colleague Nils Pratley writes that the probe must be truly independent:

Co-operative Bank scandal: bring on the inquiry, but it must be independent

The saga is an embarrassment for the Co-operative movement, UK financial regulation and – perhaps – politicians of all main parties

Andrew Tyrie, the chair of the Treasury select committee, has also said it must be chaired by an "independent person...The authorities cannot be seen to be marking their own work."

Does he have anyone specific in mind......

6.23pm GMT

The 'Cult of the high priest' quote

One of the best moments in today's hearing was when Tory MP Brian Binley accused the bankers of impersonating 'the cult of the high priest' by claiming they done a good deal (see 11.01am).

I've now found the full quote, thanks to efinancial news:

Here's how Binley let rip:

All of you have come together like you’re a professional body to defend one another....

As a taxpayer, can I say this is the cult of the high priest. It’s meant to be exclusive, meant to keep other people out, meant to say you’re much better at the job than you are, and you failed the taxpayer.

Updated at 6.39pm GMT

6.18pm GMT

The threat of a strike still hangs over Royal Mail, but it appears that some progress has been made at talks between management and union leaders today.

The Communications Workers Union has announced that the two sides have agreed to another, final, seven day extension:

There has been further progress in the negotiations between Royal Mail and CWU. Accordingly, both sides have agreed to an extension of the ballot deadline to allow for talks to continue. This is the final extension and is agreed for a further seven days.

'The CWU postal executive will meet on Monday the 25th November to consider the detailed position and determine whether industrial action should be announced.

Here's the full statement.

5.54pm GMT

The boss of Lloyds Banking Group can celebrate becoming £2.3m richer.

The bank's shares have closed at a level at which the taxpayer will make a profit on its bailing out Lloyds, for the 30th day in a row. That's enough to trigger the bonus of three million shares for its CEO, Antonio Horta Osorio.

As Jill wrote last weekend, the share bonus was Horta Osorio's idea. He can't cash in the shares until 2018 though.

Lloyds share price, for the record, closed at 75.02p tonight. The break-even point was 73.6p.

Updated at 5.55pm GMT

5.30pm GMT

Summary

The Unite union has tweeted two graphics. One showing how Royal Mail's share value has risen steadily since the flotation....

...and one showing how Goldman and UBS placed a lower valuation on Royal Mail than the banks who weren't hired to sell it:

Worth remembering that several bankers told MPs today that you can't really compare the valuations at the pitching process to the price a company is actually sold. Which raised further questions about how the City works....

5.20pm GMT

Trading on the London Stock market is over, and Royal Mail shares are unchanged on the day at 550p. A 66% increase on their flotation price in October.

UBS's sell note, and their price target of 450p, seems to have been ignored by traders.

4.51pm GMT

Back to Royal Mail, and today's committee hearing piles more pressure on Vince Cable, according to shadow trade minister Ian Murray.

Press Association has the quotes from Murray:

There are real concerns that taxpayers have lost out to the tune of hundreds of millions of pounds as a result of ministers' botched RoyalMail fire sale at a time when families are struggling with a cost-of-living crisis of David Cameron's making. 

Vince Cable has dismissed these concerns as 'froth' but this is looking less credible by the day and he has serious questions to answer. We now know he considered the option of a higher price and discussed this with banks but subsequently rejected this option. He needs to explain to the committee next week why this happened and whether political considerations played a role.

Evidence this morning highlighted that major banks including Citibank and JPMorgan, alongside Panmure Gordon, valued Royal Mail significantly above the price at which it was sold.

4.43pm GMT

In other news...

A lot of other stuff has been occurring while I was watching the BIS hearing or mopping up the reaction.

Big developments over the Co-op Group, with prime minister David Cameron floating the prospect of an inquiry into its increasingly troubled banking arm.

The issue has roared up the political agenda, with Cameron citing Labour's links to disgraced ex-chairman Paul Flowers at Prime Minister's Question's today. 

David Cameron: inquiry into Co-op Bank may be needed

In the eurozone, the euro has fallen over half a percent against the US dollar following a report saying the European Central Bank is considering imposing negative interest rates on commercial banks to encourage them to lend.

We've known for a while that this is an option, but Bloomberg suggests it's moving up the agenda: 

The euro's weakness has also pushed the pound over the €1.2 mark again. Sterling had been otherwise calm, after the latest Bank of England minutes suggested policymakers are in no rush to raise UK borrowing costs:

Dovish' Bank of England minutes lessen chances of early interest rate rise

4.16pm GMT

Veteran City commentator David Buik predicts that Vince Cable will be thoroughly quizzed next week, having watched the BIS committee "having the drains up" (classic Buik) about Royal Mail today.

Here's some highlights from his afternoon note:

Pricing an IPO is never easy. You need to please the client/government, vendors, purchasers and shareholders and there are so many imponderables in pricing the value of a company – value of assets, distribution platform, political and economic considerations – home and abroad and the size of the IPO. Royal Mail is the largest IPO since 2006.

The ability to place 600 million shares some with fund managers, some with the retail investor, 10% with the workforce with 30% remaining with the Government was no easy task. Some IPOs have fallen below this issue price. It was imperative that this did not happen to RMG.

 Richard Cormack of Goldman Sachs and James Robertson of UBS – both lead banks with Lazard Brothers - were given an extremely tough time by the chairman, Brian Binley and Mike Crockart aided and abetted by a more courteous and measured interrogation by Bill Bain, Robin Walker, Rebecca Harris and Katy Clark.....

All the banks who were interrogated insisted that submitting an initial ranging valuation was totally different from a more exact IPO valuation. My colleague at Panmure, Gert Zonneveld gave an extremely good account of himself, refusing to get sucked in to any political nuances. He felt it was his responsibility to tell his clients that in his opinion this IPO offered extremely good value.....

The committee was underwhelmed by some of the answers given. All investment banks present said a discount of between 10-15% was normal. 

The 38% premium on the first day’s trading for RMG was unusual but 30 years ago BT traded at a 30% premium. I suspect there is little correlation between these two situations. 

Brian Binley suggested that Goldman and UBS had been incompetent in seriously undervaluing the company, thus stitching the taxpayer up. Cormack and Robertson were adamant that the Government accepted their advice. I suspect that next week Dr Cable and Michael Fallon can expect a real grilling.

Buik also suggests a possible ulterior motive for the Royal Mail flotation not being priced higher -- the government has more asset sales on its agenda:

This IPO had to be a huge success to accommodate TSB, Lloyds and eventually RBS in the future. Absolutely no chance of there being any admitted tacit connection, but where there’s smoke there is sometimes fire! 

Another question for Cable....

Updated at 4.28pm GMT

3.47pm GMT

Six questions for Vince Cable

It's not surprising that Goldman Sachs' Richard Cormack looked tight-lipped leaving Portcullis House after the hearing, after being told by Brian Binley MP that Goldman's intelligence-gathering system for pricing Royal Mail had let the taxpayer down.

But in truth, the bankers weren't completely humiliated in the Grimond Room (Goldman and UBS got a sautéing rather than a full-blast grilling). No one was forced to apologise, and the two banks couldn't be shifted from their view that they'd handled the IPO in a sensible way in the circumstances.

Crucially, the three banks who placed higher valuations on the Royal Mail and were all ignored by the government didn't take the opportunity to put the leather brogues in. Panmure's Gert Zonneveld was more independent than the rest, deftly puncturing claims that the Royal Mail share surge was froth by saying markets generally price companies quite well. But there was no real dissent in the ranks.

The session has certainly lined up Vince Cable for a robust inquisition next week. A few questions spring to mind for the Business Secretary to answer:

1) Why were UBS and Goldman Sachs hired to handle the IPO, rather than JP Morgan, Citigroup or Deutsche Bank who all put a higher initial value on Royal Mail?

2) Why didn't he raise the float price to 350p in the final days, after being advised that the IPO price could be pushed up by 20p without puncturing demand?

3) Should he have postponed the float until America's debt ceiling crisis had been resolved, rather than launching the Royal Mail into a nervous market?

4) What criteria will Cable use to decide whether or not to give Goldman and UBS the £4m outstanding payment? Does he believe they did a good job, or does he share Brian Binley's fears that they were duped by City investors?

5) Does he regret criticising Gert Zonneveld's prediction in early October that Royal Mail was worth a billion pounds more than the IPO price? Does he still believe there is froth clinging to the share price?

6) Why wasn't more attention given to Royal Mail's property portfolio? The committee were startled to hear that those initial valuations from the likes of JP Morgan did not include potential future windfalls from selling surplus assets.

Updated at 5.49pm GMT

3.26pm GMT

During the session, The Times's correspondent Juliet Samuel tweeted a couple of highlights that I didn't manage to get into the blog:

3.24pm GMT

I flagged up early morning that UBS's research arm had issued a sell order on Royal Mail, claiming that the postal operator was over-priced.

They're not the only people putting out research notes on the Mail -- my colleague Nick Fletcher had rounded up the details:

Royal Mail shares dip as flotation advisor's analysts issue sell note

2.33pm GMT

Poll: Should Goldman Sachs and UBS get extra £4m for Royal Mail sale?

Based on what you've heard today, do you reckon Goldman Sachs and UBS have done well enough to earn their discretionary £4m payment from the taxpayer for handling the privatisation of Royal Mail?

Vote here:

Should Goldman Sachs and UBS get extra £4m for Royal Mail sale?

Reminder - Vince Cable must decide if the two banks have met the criteria for the payment, which apparently include working well with the government, and how the newly floated company performs. UBS agreed to sent the BIS committee the full seven points that must be met.

Updated at 2.37pm GMT

2.25pm GMT

Some more reaction to the session:

2.15pm GMT

And here's a photo of Goldman Sachs's Richard Cormack, co-head of equity capital markets, leaving Portcullis House after being told by MPs that his firm had failed the taxpayer over the sale of Royal Mail. 

1.56pm GMT

Royal Mail bankers heavily criticised by MPs - the key points

Time to recap, for new readers: 

• The two banks who handled the privatisation of Royal Mail have faced heavy criticism from MPs today.

Appearing before the Business, Innovation and Skills committee, Richard Cormack of Goldman Sachs and James Robertson, managing director of UBS, were accused of botching the flotation and costing the taxpayers many millions of pounds. <highlights of the session starts here>

Brian Binley MP told Goldman that he "wouldn't hire them again" (see here) after hearing how it and UBS had run the IPO process, which saw Royal Mail shares sold at 330p each.

Binley told the bankers he had begun to suspect their "intelligence gathering operation" was faulty, and suggested they had been duped by City investors who had suggested that they wouldn't value the postal service at more than £3.3bn.

• Goldman and UBS defended themselves, saying that the flotation was "uniquely" difficult. They tried to blame the threat of a US debt default, and the risk of strike action, for pushing down the final float price. 

Goldman's Cormack insisted that the process of 'book-building' (attracting bids from interested investors) had been performed competently. "I feel we executed the transaction well", he said.

But Binley was unconvinced, saying that he's learned early in his career that "anyone can sell cheap beer", the trick is to get the price right.

Binley urged Goldman to rethink the way it handles IPOs, saying that it "came up with the wrong answer" and fed that rogue information to the government.

Under questioning, UBS's Robertson said that the industrial unrest had been the main risk in the run-up to the float. The bankers attempted to persuade the committee that today's share price, of 538p right now, cannot be compared to the price at which you could shift 600 million shares.

• MPs also questioned whether the banks, which have already been paid over £12m in fees, should receive an extra £4m discretionary payment. It's up to the secretary of state, they replied. Over to you, Vince...

• UBS also revealed that in the final days ahead of the float, they had told the government that the price could be raised by another 20p before driving away demand. That might have raised another £120m for the taxpayer. Robertson said, though, that such a move would have been rare and tricky.

• Three investment banks who failed to be selected to handle the sale revealed that they had all valued the Royal Mail at more than the two banks who got the deal. 

JP Morgan has calculated that Royal Mail was worth up to £8.5bn, while Citi had pitched a valuation of between £5.9bn and £6.5bn (partly because it predicted a rather higher dividend payment than proved to be the case). More details.

• MPs were also astonished to hear that these valuations did not even include the potential gains from future property sales. Apparently such information simply wasn't included. UBS said that the IPO process suggested there was £100m of surplus property which could be sold.

Katy Clark MP, for one, fears that much more will be raised, depriving taxpayers of future profits.

• Gert Zonneveld, managing director at Panmure Gordon -- the first analyst to predict Royal Mail was badly undervalued -- also dismissed Vince Cable's claim that the share price jump was "froth".

Today's share price reflects the Royal Mail's true value, he said. 

Updated at 2.06pm GMT

1.47pm GMT

1.12pm GMT

How MP labelled banks as 'not very clever'

Press Association have the full quotes of the exchange between Tory MP Brian Binley and Goldman Sachs' Richard Cormack (as covered at 10.52am).

Binley said:

All the advice you gave turned out not to be helpful for the taxpayer. Right from the beginning, the Secretary of State was advised it would not go above 330p. Somebody somewhere has misled the taxpayer and cost the taxpayer.

Why do you have confidence in your intelligence gathering mechanism to suggest to the Secretary of State that you were right, when you were wrong?

Or did the Secretary of State decide for political reasons to keep the price at the lower level in order to have a successful sale?" 

Mr Binley asked whether taxpayers would be entitled to believe that the banks "were not very clever" in their job, given how much they were paid. 

After an hour of exchanges between MPs and the bankers, Mr Binley said:

I thought this might have been a political plan to keep the price down and ensure an effective, successful sale. The more I hear, I am beginning to suspect your intelligence gathering operation.

Updated at 5.50pm GMT

12.57pm GMT

Some more reaction to the session from twitter:

12.44pm GMT

As the six witnesses head back to the safety of the City, here's a snap of them in action:

From left to right, we have

  • John Mayne, Managing Director, UK Client Coverage at JP Morgan;
  • Ben Storey, Head of UK Investment Banking and Broking at Citibank;
  • James Robertson, managing director at UBS;
  • Richard Cormack, managing director, Co-Head of Equity Capital Markets at Goldman Sachs;
  • Gert Zonneveld, managing director, Co-Head of Research at Panmure Gordon, and
  • James Agnew, chairman of UK Corporate Broking, Deutsche Bank

12.39pm GMT

12.30pm GMT

Session ended with Goldman's dirty washing on display

The session finished with committee chair Adrian Bailey asking Goldman Sachs's Richard Cormack about a legal case brought against Goldman in America, over its handling of an IPO.

Cormack (who is Goldman' managing director, and co-head of equity capital markets) says he doesn't know about this.

You don't know about a 12-year old court case into how Goldman handled a flotation, queries Bailey, eyebrows heading towards the ceiling?

Cormack does not. He also doesn't know if the government considered it.

I'm quite astounded, says Bailey.

And that was the end of the hearing.

After some research, I'm pretty sure Bailey is referring to a case brought over the flotation of eToys Inc in 1999 in which Goldman played a lead role. At the time it was the fifth biggest IPO in history, but it quickly went sour. It was settled in September this year.

Reuters has the details: Goldman Sachs finally ends litigation over 1999 eToys IPO

Litigation over Goldman Sachs Group's role in the spectacular rise and fall of eToys Inc finally ended on Thursday with court approval of a $7.5 million settlement.

The online toy seller's IPO in 1999 became a poster child for the excesses of the dot-com bubble. The stock quadrupled when it began trading, but two years later the company was in bankruptcy.

The case was brought by creditors of eToys, who alleged that Goldman Sachs underpriced the stock to ensure a huge pop in price on the first day of trading.

12.17pm GMT

MPs fear taxpayers will miss out on Royal Mail property windfall

Katy Clark MP explains to UBS and Goldman that many MPs up and down the country are worried that valuable Royal Mail property will be sold off in the coming years.

She says:

What a lot of us are fearing is that assets will be sold off in our constituency, at a profit, and we won't get the benefits.

12.16pm GMT

12.15pm GMT

Katy Clark, Labour MP for North Ayrshire and Arran, also homes in on the issue of Royal Mail's excess property.

She reminds the bankers that it has 2,000 properties up and down the country. A crucial part of valuing the firm must include the prospect that some will be sold as the UK postal service develops in future.

UBS's Robertson argues that the real value of Royal Mail lies in its people, and its service, not mere bricks and mortar.

He also explains that Royal Mail has sold off £500m of surplus property assets in the run-up to the flotation. The IPO documents suggested there was another £100m of property still to be sold, so the value is priced in.

12.11pm GMT

Property valuations under scrutiny

Onto the other big question -- Royal Mail's estate of properties. What value did the investment bankers put on its excess property?

Remarkably, JP Morgan, Citigroup and Deutsche Bank all say that they didn't include the prospect of property sales in their initial valuations. Which, remember, were all higher than the £3.3bn which it was sold for (JP Morgan suggested up to £8.5bn).

Why on earth not, demands committee chair Adrian Bailey.

Apparently, it's because there was no information about surplus property in the information they were sent when they were asked to pitch.

UBS says it included a value of £200m (it, of course, was given more information once it was selected to handle the float).

Adrian Bailey looks quite aghast that something as important as Royal Mail's property portfolio might be simply ignored by investment bankers when they try to work out how much it's worth.

The committee already looked seriously unimpressed with the way the IPO was handled - and this must have added to these concerns.

12.01pm GMT

Chuka Umunna, shadow business secretary, tweets:

11.59am GMT

Should we be concerned that foreign sovereign wealth funds were allocated shares in the float? 

UBS plays down this concern, saying the Singapore sovereign wealth fund, for example, are serious investors -- not at odds with Vince Cable's goal of getting long-term blue-chip types on board.

11.52am GMT

What do these leading lights of the City think the government should do with its remaining shares in Royal Mail - sell or keep? 

No-one really sticks their neck out -- the government should wait until its six-month lock-in is over, and then take advice, says JP Morgan's John Mayne, who is managing director for UK Client Coverage,

Ben Storey, head of UK Investment Banking & Broking at Citibank, says that if conditions when the lock-up finishes are the same as today then "it may well be a good time to sell"

Gert Zonneveld, the co-head of research at Panmure Gordon, says the government should sell up if it doesn't want to be a long-term investor -- unless it thinks that there is future upside. 

11.46am GMT

Q: who made the final decision on the 330p price that Royal Mail was sold at?

Goldman: the Secretary of State and the government made the final decision.

Was it consistent with advise from UBS and Goldman?

Yes, adds Cormack.

11.44am GMT

Great question - about the discretionary payment of £4.2m that Goldman and UBS could receive.

Do you think taxpayers will welcome you receiving it with open arms?

UBS's Robertson demures: I think that's for the secretary of state to decide - it's in his gift.

11.42am GMT

UBS's James Robertson adds that the bankers discussed the possibility of raising the price with Lazard, which was acting for the government, in the final days before the float.

"We don't take raising money for the taxpayer lightly -- we discussed this with Lazard, and they discussed with the Secretary of State", he added.

11.40am GMT

A question about why UBS and Goldman recommended not raising the IPO price as the float date approached.

UBS's Robertson says that they advised the government in the 'final days' is that they could have raised an extra 20p before demand fell off sharply.

He explains:

We gave it serious consideration as obviously 20p is a lot of money.

(there's a phrase you don't expect to hear from a banker)

So why didn't they do it?

Well, it's pretty rare, says Robertson. -- extending the price has only been done once in the last 13 years, they'd have had to offer withdrawal rights to 650,000 retail investors (possible, but tricky). And the US default and the balletballot on strike action were both looming -- they could have wiped out the positive momentum.

They didn't, though....

Updated at 12.31pm GMT

11.35am GMT

Committee chair Adrian Bailey wants to see the report that Goldman prepared on the float and gave to Vince Cable.

It was a confidential report....We'll have to talk about it with our client, Cormack explains.

11.33am GMT

UBS's Robertson repeats that "this was a uniquely risky and difficult IPO". It's hard to float a company that doesn't have a track record of profitability, for example.

Update: he's also making the point that it was a tricky time to float Royal Mail shares, given industrial action at home, and the US debt ceiling crisis abroad. 

Updated at 1.03pm GMT

11.33am GMT

MP: Goldman should change its ways

Brian Binley again. He asks Goldman's Cormack whether he thinks the bankers' "intelligence-gathering" activities were exploited by the potential investors who said how much they'd be prepared to pay for Royal Mail.

Cormack starts to run through the process again, but is interrupted quickly by Binley, who says:

I was in the business of selling beer, years ago. Anyone can sell cheap beer.

What i'm suggesting is that you got this wrong, and you should look at your product to that next time you sell a better product to a satisfied customer, Binley adds.

Cormack give no indication that Goldman will change its ways: We were seeking a broad-base of long-term investors who would provide broad-based support to the government and give access to the capital markets, he adds.

The people who have been buying shares subsequently might not have paid as much in the IPO process. The process we we used was the right one, he insists.…

Oh dear, I'm not convinced, says Binley, dropping his pen on the table in disgust.

11.22am GMT

Why didn't UBS and Goldman Sachs spot all the positive newspaper commentary, saying Royal Mail looked undervalued? 

GS's Cormack replies that the media initially had a balanced view of the IPO, and only turned much more positive in the final days.

11.17am GMT

Did you discount the interest from short-term investors, and what impact did that have?

Goldman Sachs' Cormack says that the book-builders did focus on the interests of the long-term shareholders (which Vince Cable wanted to attract), but he don't think this materially affect the value of Royal Mail.

11.11am GMT

What will the Royal Mail share price be in six months time?

None of the five investment bankers wants to give a price -- JP Morgan, Citi and Deutsche Bank say they've not been closely involved with the company for six months, having not been chosen to handle the float.

UBS's Robertson says there's various factors to consider, including industrial relations and the possibility of VAT being added to postal products.

But Panmure's Zonneveld isn't so bashful -- he's got a target price of 570p. And he stands by comments made to the Guardian on October 25th that Royal Mail has good prospects.

11.05am GMT

Is Vince Cable right that the Royal Mail's soaring share price is merely 'froth'"?

Most of the bankers say that such early spikes are common. UBS's managing director James Robertson says its "not unusual" to see this kind of thing.

But Gert Zonneveld, Managing Director at Panmure Gordon, sinks the very notion of froth.

This is not froth....the shares have been trading for six weeks.

Markets are quite efficient, he says, adding

Today's value is the price that the markets place on it.

11.01am GMT

Brian Binley is back-- accusing the bankers of all defending each other.

He suggests that these senior City players are painting a picture of "The cult of the high priest" surrounding the IPO process.

Isn't the truth that you simply undervalued Royal Mail, and cost the taxpayer money?

Goldman's Cormack doesn't accept this.

I feel that we executed the transaction well for the interests of the taxpayer

"Well, I wouldn't hire you again," Binley replies.

10.58am GMT

MPs ask the banks who missed out on handling the float how much the government could sell its remaining shares for. How much of a discount would be needed?

None will give a clear answer. But Ben Storey, head of UK Investment Banking & Broking at Citibank, says that October's float took place in a "clearly challenging" environment. Market sentiment has improved since, he adds.

JP Morgan's John Mayne agrees that some discount would be needed.

10.53am GMT

10.52am GMT

MP doubts Goldman and UBS's 'intelligence-gathering' powers

Tory MP Brian Binley gives Goldman and UBS a serious dressing down.

He says that his initial concern was that the government wanted to get a low price to ensure success.

"But, now I'm starting to doubt your intelligence-gathering abilities."

Your advice and the process you ran has damaged the taxpayer, Binley adds.

Goldman Sachs's Richard Cormack defends the banks, saying they had run a "market-led book building process" which had, in his view, successfully delivered a good price.

Binley is unimpressed, saying "Someone somewhere has misled the taxpayer and cost the taxpayer."

Were you wrong, or did the Secretary of State keep the price low to ensure a successful sale?

Cormack replies that: based on all our research, 330p was the price we could achieve for the amount of shares we were selling,says Cormack.

For all the money you were paid, you aren't very good at your job, shoots back Binley.

Cormack denies it -- saying:

This was a large, complicated deal against a difficult backdrop in the markets with the debt ceiling, and the threat of industrial action.... In the context it was a well-execute transaction.

10.43am GMT

Was the US debt ceiling deadlock another factor, as Vince Cable has suggested?

Goldman's Cormack says it was -- the London stock market fell for 12 days in a row as investors feared a catastrophic default.

It was certainly a factor stopping us raising the IPO price, he adds.

But you're a bright man, surely you knew that US politicians would resolve the dilemma. 

There's always a danger that a deal wouldn't be reached, Cormack adds.

10.41am GMT

UBS's Robertson adds that from September onwards the threat of a Royal Mail strike over pay was the main "risk factor" hanging over the IPO.

10.40am GMT

We've moved onto a key issue -- whether the threat of industrial action pushed down Royal Mail's float price.

UBS's James Robertson says that the "appetite" for Royal Mail shares had been coloured by the prospect of a strike.

So how much did you change your value by?

The strike threat affected the view fo what they theyt were prepare to pay andit set the range of 260 to 330

By how much?

It's hard to say.

Did you feed this back to Vince Cable?

Yes, says Goldman's Cormack.

10.33am GMT

The bankers are asked about Vince Cable's claim in a letter that some large investors had threatened to walk away if the price rose above 330p.

Goldman's Cormack confirms these comments. He doesn't know whether those same firms have since bought shares in the stock market (at above 330p, of course) -- but we'll find out eventually when the Royal Mail investor list is updated.

Updated at 10.34am GMT

10.30am GMT

Goldman's Cormack says that it was important to sell a majority of Royal Mail shares, and also to retain a large majority for the taxpayer so they can benefit it the share price is higher in the long term. 

10.28am GMT

The committee aren't sounding impressed by the process by which the Royal Mail was valued and processed. It sounds like banks are incentivised to pitch the value too low and then drag it up.

Goldman's Cormack paints a more positive picture - saying that GS and UBS used the book building process to 'walk people up' from their original lower bids towards the 330p final price.

10.24am GMT

Goldman's Cormack says it takes time for a share price to settle after flotation.

Updated at 10.24am GMT

10.23am GMT

UBS's Richardson says there have been eight other IPOs this year in London --- four are trading at least 60% higher than the float, 2 are 25% higher, and 2 are down at least 20%.

10.22am GMT

Goldman Sach's initial pitch for Royal Mail valued it at between £3bn and £3.7bn, later settling on £3.25bn to £3.5bn with a maximum of £3.75bn.

10.20am GMT

UBS's James Robertson says that the Royal Mail should be pleased that much of the shares in the float were sold to "long-term blue chip" investors.

He's reminded that a hedge fund, the Children's Investment Fund, has been steadily building a stake in the Royal Mail. Has that pushed the share price up? Robertson says it has.

10.18am GMT

Gert Zonneveld of Panmure Gordon is reminded that Vince Cable dismissed his valuation as an "outlier" when he suggested that Royal Mail might be worth up to £4,5bn in the weeks leading to the float. Is he unhappy about that?

Zonneveld plays it cool - saying he's pleased that his research has been vindicated. I"m not concerned about the Secretary of State's comments, he suggests.

Chairman Adrian Bailey calls him up on this, saying that sounds like Zonneveld is "deeply concerned".

When Vince Cable said he didn't want to rubbish you, well "in political terms it means that he does want to rubbish you", Bailey says.

Zonneveld responds:

He's a politician, playing politics is what he does.

I was the only guy in the market with a view apart from the syndicate banks, he added.

10.12am GMT

Do you accept that you undervalued the company?

Goldman's Cormack argues not. He says that you can't expect to sell £2bn of shares, 600m in total, at the same price that just 1.6 million are changing hands today.

10.09am GMT

MPs are keen to find why UBS and Goldman Sachs reckoned Royal Mail was worth less than three other banks - JP Morgan, Citi and Deutsche.

James Robertson of UBS says that Royal Mail had no track record of profitability, and faced various risks.

Goldman's Richard Cormack says that the valuation at IPO should be divorced from the value at the time of the pitching process. We are all doing outside-in valuation, he says. 

10.05am GMT

Panmure's initial valuation was between £4bn and £5bn, but it later settled on a valuation of £3.7bn to £4.5bn, says Gert Zonneveld.

10.04am GMT

Why were the valuations so different? From £3.1bn to over £8bn?

Citi's Ben Storey explains that it's actually quite hard to value a company from outside, as you have to make many assumptions. These were preliminary valuations, which can't really be compared to the final floatation value.

He says that Citi had a higher expectation for Royal Mail's dividend payment than proved correct.

10.00am GMT

UBS's James Robertson says that it initially valued Royal Mail at £3.1bn, rising to £4.6bn if various risks were resolved.

He explains that UBS asked for a base fee of 0.9% of the money raised, plus a 0.3% incentive fee.

What is the criteria for getting the bonus fee?

Various factors, including the 'after market' performance, and working well with the seller.

9.56am GMT

Is there an incentive for winning banks to pitch a low valuation, and then look successful by getting a higher price?

Goldman's Cormack denies it -- the incentive is to get a fair valuation.

9.53am GMT

The Banks valuations of Royal Mail

MPs are getting details from the banks who weren't selected to hold the flotation.

And they're pretty interesting.

JP Morgan's John Mayne says that it valued Royal Mail at between £6.8bn and £8.5bn

Citigroup's Ben Storey says it said valued Royal Mail at between £5.9bn and £6.5bn.

Deutsche Bank's James Agnew says it offered a valuation of £5.5bn and £6bn.

A reminder -- Royal Mail was sold at a valuation of £3.3bn - and is currently worth around £5.4bn.

And what fees did they ask for?

It's a complicated answer, as the fees are dependent on the price of the sale. But Citi's valuation would have delivered total fees for all the bankers involved of £14m, and Deutsche's would be £16m.

Updated at 9.55am GMT

9.43am GMT

So what was the rational for getting selected? Goldman's Cormack says that it was wide-ranging, including how a bank would pitch the sale to investors, what they valued it at, and how they'd like to be paid.

9.39am GMT

Confirmation that the two banks who got the deal, Goldman and UBS, have received £13m of fees so far.

9.37am GMT

Richard Cormack of Goldman Sachs takes the first question. He explains that the government approached the main investment banks and asked then to pitch.

What was the criteria, asks Bailey?

An understanding of the company, a track record of handling such sales, and their general competence, Cormack explains.

Was there any reason why the government's couldn't hold a Dutch auction?

Cormack argues that the approach used was in line with the government's policies, and general City practice.

9.31am GMT

We're underway, with Adrian Bailey asking the six bankers present to explain how the process of becoming an adviser to the float worked....

9.28am GMT

Watch the session here

The BIS committee hearing should start shortly, in the Grimond Room at Portcullis House.

It's being streamed live here. 

9.16am GMT

On the issue of withholding fees from Goldman Sachs and UBS... they have already received around £12.7m for their work on the Royal Mail float, but there's another £4.2m waiting to be paid at the discretion of the government.

Adrian Bailey, the chair of the BIS committee, has already said MPs will examine whether Goldman and UBS will get the outstanding payment.

As my colleague Sean Farrell reported on Sunday, Bailey has said:

Questions need to be asked about the criteria used to qualify for the deferred payment.

Katy Clark, a Labour member of the committee, is keen to find out exactly what the investment banks told the government before it decided the pricing of Royal Mail.

Clark said:

We want to hear what officials were told. What was the basis on which the advice was provided – and if the asset was worth a huge amount more, was that information given to the secretary of state [Vince Cable] and why wasn't it proceeded on?

Cable will appear before the committee next week....

Updated at 9.24am GMT

9.03am GMT

A prediction: MPs will hear that pricing stock market flotations is a devilishly tricky art.

Bankers could also cite some high-profile recent IPOs that bombed -- such as Facebook, whose shares sunk when it floated last year (they've rallied hard since, though).

As Bloomberg's Caroline Hyde put it:

It's a very difficult art to price these floats.

In the City, traders often talk about how newly listed companies should 'pop' on their first day's trading. But the problem with using this argument for Royal Mail is that the share have soared by 60% since the float. More a boom than a pop.

Updated at 9.03am GMT

8.48am GMT

Unions want bank payments withheld

The Communications Workers Union is calling for the government to withhold outstanding payments to the bankers who advised it on the Royal Mail float. 

The CWU's general secretary, Billy Hayes, said:

Hundreds of millions of pounds of taxpayers' money have been lost because of the failure of the government and its advisers to accurately value the company. In other situations this would be gross incompetence or even theft. Private shareholders have lined their pockets at the expense of the taxpayer following the huge leap in the share price.

At the very least the institutions which advised the government should not receive any further payments, which are discretionary. Serious consideration should be given to claiming back fees paid for shoddy advice which has left the client – the taxpayer – out of pocket.

I suspect that it won't be possible to claim back those fees already paid - but MPs will raise the issue this morning....

Here's the full story: Royal Mail sale valuation branded a debacle by union

Updated at 9.23am GMT

8.40am GMT

Shares in Royal Mail are down 2% this morning, ahead of the BIS committee hearing.

They've dropped 11p in early trading to 530p, valuing the company at £5.39bn. That's still 60% higher than the flotation price (in mid-October).

This may be triggered by a research note from UBS analysts, who have slapped a 'sell' rating on Royal Mail shares and set a target price of 450p.

Something for UBS's managing director, James Robertson, to ponder ahead of his appearance before MPs in an hour's time.

Two other analyst houses also published research notes on Royal Mail this morning. Barclays set a target price of 466p, while RBC is more optimistic - it reckons Royal Mail shares are worth 580p. 

Updated at 8.40am GMT

8.15am GMT

Bankers to be quizzed over Royal Mail float

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of events across the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and the business world.

It's rare to see investment bankers called to account for their actions. But today, the top people who advised the government the controversial flotation of Royal Mail face a grilling by MPs.

The Business, Investment and Skills committee will demand answers from Goldman Sachs and UBS, who ran the float, on how the postal service was sold off at £3.3bn. It immediately saw its shares soar 38% when trading began last month, and is now valued at over £5bn.

The line-up includes JP Morgan -- who apparently told the government during the pricing process that Royal Mail could be worth £10bn -- and Panmure Gordon, the broker who warned that the sale was undervalued.

Citi and Deutsche Bank, who also missed out on running the IPO, make up the sextet.

The hearing starts at 9.30am. Here's who's attending:

  • John Mayne, Managing Director, UK Client Coverage, JP Morgan
  • Ben Storey, Head of UK Investment Banking & Broking, Citibank
  • Gert Zonneveld, Managing Director, Co-Head of Research, Panmure Gordon
  • James Agnew, Chairman of UK Corporate Broking, Deutsche Bank
  • James Robertson, Managing Director, UBS
  • Richard Cormack, Managing Director, Co-Head of Equity Capital Markets, Goldman Sachs

Royal Mail's not the only story in town, though.

The Co-op Group remains in the news for the wrong reasons, as the scandal around former Bank chairman Paul Flowers swirls. Police search home of former Co-op Bank boss.

We'll also be looking at central banks, with the publication of the latest Bank of England minutes at 9.30am GMT (just as the Royal Mail hearing starts...).

They'll give an insight into how the Monetary Policy Committee sees the UK economy (the BoE was pretty upbeat at last week's quarterly inflation report).

The US Federal Reserve is also releasing its latest minutes tonight, but the markets have already got a large dollop of wisdom from its outgoing chair, Ben Bernanke, to digest. Overnight, he declared that the Fed was committed to ultra-loose monetary policy for as long as needed -- suggesting no early tightening of its huge stimulus programme. 

Despite this promise of yet more easy money, Europe's stock markets are expected to slide this morning. Trading has begun, with the FTSE 100 is down 0.4%, or 21 points, at 6670.

And we'll also be watching Greece, where talks between the government and its troika of lenders appear to be gummed down.

I'll be tracking all the action through the day....

Updated at 8.27am GMT
fields.bodyText: Time to wrap up here, as postal workers around the UK crack on with processing tonight's mail for the morning. Our news story on today's hearing, just launched, is here: Royal Mail float: paying bankers' deferred fees would be 'mad', MP says Highlights of today's session at the BIS committee start here. My summary of the key points is here. There's reaction here, and again here. You can still vote in our poll on whether Goldman Sachs and UBS should get their outstanding payment for their work on the Mail sale. And here's a few questions which Vince Cable might like to ponder. We'll be back tomorrow, with more general coverage of events - having rather gone postal today. Cheers, and goodnight. GW. Some late news: Adrian Bailey, the chair of the BIS committee, has told the Guardian that the government would be "mad" to pay Goldman Sachs and UBS the outstanding £4m fees they could receive for their work on Royal Mail. My colleague Sean Farrell has the story. The government would be "mad" to pay more than £4m of deferred fees to the banks that advised on Royal Mail's privatisation because they undervalued the company, the chairman of a powerful parliamentary committee said after grilling the bankers on Wednesday. Adrian Bailey, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) Select Committee, said paying the fees, on top of more than £12m already handed over, would reward highly paid bankers who set the float price too low at the expense of the taxpayer. Bailey gave his judgment after the committee had quizzed senior bankers from Goldman Sachs and UBS, the banks that led the flotation. In more than two hours of questioning they were accused of failing at their jobs and selling the taxpayer short. The government sold 60% of Royal Mail at 330p a share last month, valuing the company at £3.3bn. But the shares leapt 38% on their first day of trading and closed tonight at 550p, giving Royal Mail a market value of £5.5bn. Goldman, UBS and five other banks that marketed the shares have so far been paid £12.7m between them but they could get another £4.2m if Vince Cable, the secretary of state, thinks they warrant it. Bailey said: "The government, in view of what has happened subsequently, would be mad to give them [the money]. "It would be seen as rewarding the private sector that lost the tax payer potentially £1bn and in these days of austerity I think it would be a very politically dangerous thing to do. These are professional people, who got it wrong, and they would be rewarded despite the fact they got it wrong." Here's the full story: Royal Mail float: paying bankers' deferred fees would be 'mad', MP says On the inquiry into the Co-op Bank scandal, my colleague Nils Pratley writes that the probe must be truly independent: Co-operative Bank scandal: bring on the inquiry, but it must be independent The saga is an embarrassment for the Co-operative movement, UK financial regulation and – perhaps – politicians of all main parties Andrew Tyrie, the chair of the Treasury select committee, has also said it must be chaired by an "independent person...The authorities cannot be seen to be marking their own work." Does he have anyone specific in mind...... One of the best moments in today's hearing was when Tory MP Brian Binley accused the bankers of impersonating 'the cult of the high priest' by claiming they done a good deal (see 11.01am). I've now found the full quote, thanks to efinancial news: Here's how Binley let rip: All of you have come together like you’re a professional body to defend one another.... As a taxpayer, can I say this is the cult of the high priest. It’s meant to be exclusive, meant to keep other people out, meant to say you’re much better at the job than you are, and you failed the taxpayer. The threat of a strike still hangs over Royal Mail, but it appears that some progress has been made at talks between management and union leaders today. The Communications Workers Union has announced that the two sides have agreed to another, final, seven day extension: There has been further progress in the negotiations between Royal Mail and CWU. Accordingly, both sides have agreed to an extension of the ballot deadline to allow for talks to continue. This is the final extension and is agreed for a further seven days. 'The CWU postal executive will meet on Monday the 25th November to consider the detailed position and determine whether industrial action should be announced. Here's the full statement. The boss of Lloyds Banking Group can celebrate becoming £2.3m richer. The bank's shares have closed at a level at which the taxpayer will make a profit on its bailing out Lloyds, for the 30th day in a row. That's enough to trigger the bonus of three million shares for its CEO, Antonio Horta Osorio. As Jill wrote last weekend, the share bonus was Horta Osorio's idea. He can't cash in the shares until 2018 though. Lloyds share price, for the record, closed at 75.02p tonight. The break-even point was 73.6p. The Unite union has tweeted two graphics. One showing how Royal Mail's share value has risen steadily since the flotation.... ...and one showing how Goldman and UBS placed a lower valuation on Royal Mail than the banks who weren't hired to sell it: Worth remembering that several bankers told MPs today that you can't really compare the valuations at the pitching process to the price a company is actually sold. Which raised further questions about how the City works.... Trading on the London Stock market is over, and Royal Mail shares are unchanged on the day at 550p. A 66% increase on their flotation price in October. UBS's sell note, and their price target of 450p, seems to have been ignored by traders. Back to Royal Mail, and today's committee hearing piles more pressure on Vince Cable, according to shadow trade minister Ian Murray. Press Association has the quotes from Murray: There are real concerns that taxpayers have lost out to the tune of hundreds of millions of pounds as a result of ministers' botched RoyalMail fire sale at a time when families are struggling with a cost-of-living crisis of David Cameron's making. Vince Cable has dismissed these concerns as 'froth' but this is looking less credible by the day and he has serious questions to answer. We now know he considered the option of a higher price and discussed this with banks but subsequently rejected this option. He needs to explain to the committee next week why this happened and whether political considerations played a role. Evidence this morning highlighted that major banks including Citibank and JPMorgan, alongside Panmure Gordon, valued Royal Mail significantly above the price at which it was sold. A lot of other stuff has been occurring while I was watching the BIS hearing or mopping up the reaction. Big developments over the Co-op Group, with prime minister David Cameron floating the prospect of an inquiry into its increasingly troubled banking arm. The issue has roared up the political agenda, with Cameron citing Labour's links to disgraced ex-chairman Paul Flowers at Prime Minister's Question's today. David Cameron: inquiry into Co-op Bank may be needed In the eurozone, the euro has fallen over half a percent against the US dollar following a report saying the European Central Bank is considering imposing negative interest rates on commercial banks to encourage them to lend. We've known for a while that this is an option, but Bloomberg suggests it's moving up the agenda: The euro's weakness has also pushed the pound over the €1.2 mark again. Sterling had been otherwise calm, after the latest Bank of England minutes suggested policymakers are in no rush to raise UK borrowing costs: Dovish' Bank of England minutes lessen chances of early interest rate rise Veteran City commentator David Buik predicts that Vince Cable will be thoroughly quizzed next week, having watched the BIS committee "having the drains up" (classic Buik) about Royal Mail today. Here's some highlights from his afternoon note: Pricing an IPO is never easy. You need to please the client/government, vendors, purchasers and shareholders and there are so many imponderables in pricing the value of a company – value of assets, distribution platform, political and economic considerations – home and abroad and the size of the IPO. Royal Mail is the largest IPO since 2006. The ability to place 600 million shares some with fund managers, some with the retail investor, 10% with the workforce with 30% remaining with the Government was no easy task. Some IPOs have fallen below this issue price. It was imperative that this did not happen to RMG. Richard Cormack of Goldman Sachs and James Robertson of UBS – both lead banks with Lazard Brothers - were given an extremely tough time by the chairman, Brian Binley and Mike Crockart aided and abetted by a more courteous and measured interrogation by Bill Bain, Robin Walker, Rebecca Harris and Katy Clark..... All the banks who were interrogated insisted that submitting an initial ranging valuation was totally different from a more exact IPO valuation. My colleague at Panmure, Gert Zonneveld gave an extremely good account of himself, refusing to get sucked in to any political nuances. He felt it was his responsibility to tell his clients that in his opinion this IPO offered extremely good value..... The committee was underwhelmed by some of the answers given. All investment banks present said a discount of between 10-15% was normal. The 38% premium on the first day’s trading for RMG was unusual but 30 years ago BT traded at a 30% premium. I suspect there is little correlation between these two situations. Brian Binley suggested that Goldman and UBS had been incompetent in seriously undervaluing the company, thus stitching the taxpayer up. Cormack and Robertson were adamant that the Government accepted their advice. I suspect that next week Dr Cable and Michael Fallon can expect a real grilling. Buik also suggests a possible ulterior motive for the Royal Mail flotation not being priced higher -- the government has more asset sales on its agenda: This IPO had to be a huge success to accommodate TSB, Lloyds and eventually RBS in the future. Absolutely no chance of there being any admitted tacit connection, but where there’s smoke there is sometimes fire! Another question for Cable.... It's not surprising that Goldman Sachs' Richard Cormack looked tight-lipped leaving Portcullis House after the hearing, after being told by Brian Binley MP that Goldman's intelligence-gathering system for pricing Royal Mail had let the taxpayer down. But in truth, the bankers weren't completely humiliated in the Grimond Room (Goldman and UBS got a sautéing rather than a full-blast grilling). No one was forced to apologise, and the two banks couldn't be shifted from their view that they'd handled the IPO in a sensible way in the circumstances. Crucially, the three banks who placed higher valuations on the Royal Mail and were all ignored by the government didn't take the opportunity to put the leather brogues in. Panmure's Gert Zonneveld was more independent than the rest, deftly puncturing claims that the Royal Mail share surge was froth by saying markets generally price companies quite well. But there was no real dissent in the ranks. The session has certainly lined up Vince Cable for a robust inquisition next week. A few questions spring to mind for the Business Secretary to answer: 1) Why were UBS and Goldman Sachs hired to handle the IPO, rather than JP Morgan, Citigroup or Deutsche Bank who all put a higher initial value on Royal Mail? 2) Why didn't he raise the float price to 350p in the final days, after being advised that the IPO price could be pushed up by 20p without puncturing demand? 3) Should he have postponed the float until America's debt ceiling crisis had been resolved, rather than launching the Royal Mail into a nervous market? 4) What criteria will Cable use to decide whether or not to give Goldman and UBS the £4m outstanding payment?
