Does he believe they did a good job, or does he share Brian Binley's fears that they were duped by City investors? 5) Does he regret criticising Gert Zonneveld's prediction in early October that Royal Mail was worth a billion pounds more than the IPO price? Does he still believe there is froth clinging to the share price? 6) Why wasn't more attention given to Royal Mail's property portfolio? The committee were startled to hear that those initial valuations from the likes of JP Morgan did not include potential future windfalls from selling surplus assets. During the session, The Times's correspondent Juliet Samuel tweeted a couple of highlights that I didn't manage to get into the blog: I flagged up early morning that UBS's research arm had issued a sell order on Royal Mail, claiming that the postal operator was over-priced. They're not the only people putting out research notes on the Mail -- my colleague Nick Fletcher had rounded up the details: Royal Mail shares dip as flotation advisor's analysts issue sell note Based on what you've heard today, do you reckon Goldman Sachs and UBS have done well enough to earn their discretionary £4m payment from the taxpayer for handling the privatisation of Royal Mail? Vote here: Should Goldman Sachs and UBS get extra £4m for Royal Mail sale? Reminder - Vince Cable must decide if the two banks have met the criteria for the payment, which apparently include working well with the government, and how the newly floated company performs. UBS agreed to sent the BIS committee the full seven points that must be met. Some more reaction to the session: And here's a photo of Goldman Sachs's Richard Cormack, co-head of equity capital markets, leaving Portcullis House after being told by MPs that his firm had failed the taxpayer over the sale of Royal Mail. Time to recap, for new readers: • The two banks who handled the privatisation of Royal Mail have faced heavy criticism from MPs today. Appearing before the Business, Innovation and Skills committee, Richard Cormack of Goldman Sachs and James Robertson, managing director of UBS, were accused of botching the flotation and costing the taxpayers many millions of pounds.  Brian Binley MP told Goldman that he "wouldn't hire them again" (see here) after hearing how it and UBS had run the IPO process, which saw Royal Mail shares sold at 330p each. Binley told the bankers he had begun to suspect their "intelligence gathering operation" was faulty, and suggested they had been duped by City investors who had suggested that they wouldn't value the postal service at more than £3.3bn. • Goldman and UBS defended themselves, saying that the flotation was "uniquely" difficult. They tried to blame the threat of a US debt default, and the risk of strike action, for pushing down the final float price. Goldman's Cormack insisted that the process of 'book-building' (attracting bids from interested investors) had been performed competently. "I feel we executed the transaction well", he said. But Binley was unconvinced, saying that he's learned early in his career that "anyone can sell cheap beer", the trick is to get the price right. Binley urged Goldman to rethink the way it handles IPOs, saying that it "came up with the wrong answer" and fed that rogue information to the government. Under questioning, UBS's Robertson said that the industrial unrest had been the main risk in the run-up to the float. The bankers attempted to persuade the committee that today's share price, of 538p right now, cannot be compared to the price at which you could shift 600 million shares. • MPs also questioned whether the banks, which have already been paid over £12m in fees, should receive an extra £4m discretionary payment. It's up to the secretary of state, they replied. Over to you, Vince... • UBS also revealed that in the final days ahead of the float, they had told the government that the price could be raised by another 20p before driving away demand. That might have raised another £120m for the taxpayer. Robertson said, though, that such a move would have been rare and tricky. • Three investment banks who failed to be selected to handle the sale revealed that they had all valued the Royal Mail at more than the two banks who got the deal. JP Morgan has calculated that Royal Mail was worth up to £8.5bn, while Citi had pitched a valuation of between £5.9bn and £6.5bn (partly because it predicted a rather higher dividend payment than proved to be the case). More details. • MPs were also astonished to hear that these valuations did not even include the potential gains from future property sales. Apparently such information simply wasn't included. UBS said that the IPO process suggested there was £100m of surplus property which could be sold. Katy Clark MP, for one, fears that much more will be raised, depriving taxpayers of future profits. • Gert Zonneveld, managing director at Panmure Gordon -- the first analyst to predict Royal Mail was badly undervalued -- also dismissed Vince Cable's claim that the share price jump was "froth". Today's share price reflects the Royal Mail's true value, he said. Press Association have the full quotes of the exchange between Tory MP Brian Binley and Goldman Sachs' Richard Cormack (as covered at 10.52am). Binley said: All the advice you gave turned out not to be helpful for the taxpayer. Right from the beginning, the Secretary of State was advised it would not go above 330p. Somebody somewhere has misled the taxpayer and cost the taxpayer. Why do you have confidence in your intelligence gathering mechanism to suggest to the Secretary of State that you were right, when you were wrong? Or did the Secretary of State decide for political reasons to keep the price at the lower level in order to have a successful sale?" Mr Binley asked whether taxpayers would be entitled to believe that the banks "were not very clever" in their job, given how much they were paid. After an hour of exchanges between MPs and the bankers, Mr Binley said: I thought this might have been a political plan to keep the price down and ensure an effective, successful sale. The more I hear, I am beginning to suspect your intelligence gathering operation. Some more reaction to the session from twitter: As the six witnesses head back to the safety of the City, here's a snap of them in action: From left to right, we have John Mayne, Managing Director, UK Client Coverage at JP Morgan; Ben Storey, Head of UK Investment Banking and Broking at Citibank; James Robertson, managing director at UBS; Richard Cormack, managing director, Co-Head of Equity Capital Markets at Goldman Sachs; Gert Zonneveld, managing director, Co-Head of Research at Panmure Gordon, and James Agnew, chairman of UK Corporate Broking, Deutsche Bank The session finished with committee chair Adrian Bailey asking Goldman Sachs's Richard Cormack about a legal case brought against Goldman in America, over its handling of an IPO. Cormack (who is Goldman' managing director, and co-head of equity capital markets) says he doesn't know about this. You don't know about a 12-year old court case into how Goldman handled a flotation, queries Bailey, eyebrows heading towards the ceiling? Cormack does not. He also doesn't know if the government considered it. I'm quite astounded, says Bailey. And that was the end of the hearing. After some research, I'm pretty sure Bailey is referring to a case brought over the flotation of eToys Inc in 1999 in which Goldman played a lead role. At the time it was the fifth biggest IPO in history, but it quickly went sour. It was settled in September this year. Reuters has the details: Goldman Sachs finally ends litigation over 1999 eToys IPO Litigation over Goldman Sachs Group's role in the spectacular rise and fall of eToys Inc finally ended on Thursday with court approval of a $7.5 million settlement. The online toy seller's IPO in 1999 became a poster child for the excesses of the dot-com bubble. The stock quadrupled when it began trading, but two years later the company was in bankruptcy. The case was brought by creditors of eToys, who alleged that Goldman Sachs underpriced the stock to ensure a huge pop in price on the first day of trading. Katy Clark MP explains to UBS and Goldman that many MPs up and down the country are worried that valuable Royal Mail property will be sold off in the coming years. She says: What a lot of us are fearing is that assets will be sold off in our constituency, at a profit, and we won't get the benefits. Katy Clark, Labour MP for North Ayrshire and Arran, also homes in on the issue of Royal Mail's excess property. She reminds the bankers that it has 2,000 properties up and down the country. A crucial part of valuing the firm must include the prospect that some will be sold as the UK postal service develops in future. UBS's Robertson argues that the real value of Royal Mail lies in its people, and its service, not mere bricks and mortar. He also explains that Royal Mail has sold off £500m of surplus property assets in the run-up to the flotation. The IPO documents suggested there was another £100m of property still to be sold, so the value is priced in. Onto the other big question -- Royal Mail's estate of properties. What value did the investment bankers put on its excess property? Remarkably, JP Morgan, Citigroup and Deutsche Bank all say that they didn't include the prospect of property sales in their initial valuations. Which, remember, were all higher than the £3.3bn which it was sold for (JP Morgan suggested up to £8.5bn). Why on earth not, demands committee chair Adrian Bailey. Apparently, it's because there was no information about surplus property in the information they were sent when they were asked to pitch. UBS says it included a value of £200m (it, of course, was given more information once it was selected to handle the float). Adrian Bailey looks quite aghast that something as important as Royal Mail's property portfolio might be simply ignored by investment bankers when they try to work out how much it's worth. The committee already looked seriously unimpressed with the way the IPO was handled - and this must have added to these concerns. Chuka Umunna, shadow business secretary, tweets: Should we be concerned that foreign sovereign wealth funds were allocated shares in the float? UBS plays down this concern, saying the Singapore sovereign wealth fund, for example, are serious investors -- not at odds with Vince Cable's goal of getting long-term blue-chip types on board. What do these leading lights of the City think the government should do with its remaining shares in Royal Mail - sell or keep? No-one really sticks their neck out -- the government should wait until its six-month lock-in is over, and then take advice, says JP Morgan's John Mayne, who is managing director for UK Client Coverage, Ben Storey, head of UK Investment Banking & Broking at Citibank, says that if conditions when the lock-up finishes are the same as today then "it may well be a good time to sell" Gert Zonneveld, the co-head of research at Panmure Gordon, says the government should sell up if it doesn't want to be a long-term investor -- unless it thinks that there is future upside. Q: who made the final decision on the 330p price that Royal Mail was sold at? Goldman: the Secretary of State and the government made the final decision. Was it consistent with advise from UBS and Goldman? Yes, adds Cormack. Great question - about the discretionary payment of £4.2m that Goldman and UBS could receive. Do you think taxpayers will welcome you receiving it with open arms? UBS's Robertson demures: I think that's for the secretary of state to decide - it's in his gift. UBS's James Robertson adds that the bankers discussed the possibility of raising the price with Lazard, which was acting for the government, in the final days before the float. "We don't take raising money for the taxpayer lightly -- we discussed this with Lazard, and they discussed with the Secretary of State", he added. A question about why UBS and Goldman recommended not raising the IPO price as the float date approached. UBS's Robertson says that they advised the government in the 'final days' is that they could have raised an extra 20p before demand fell off sharply. He explains: We gave it serious consideration as obviously 20p is a lot of money. (there's a phrase you don't expect to hear from a banker) So why didn't they do it? Well, it's pretty rare, says Robertson. -- extending the price has only been done once in the last 13 years, they'd have had to offer withdrawal rights to 650,000 retail investors (possible, but tricky). And the US default and the balletballot on strike action were both looming -- they could have wiped out the positive momentum. They didn't, though.... Committee chair Adrian Bailey wants to see the report that Goldman prepared on the float and gave to Vince Cable. It was a confidential report....We'll have to talk about it with our client, Cormack explains. UBS's Robertson repeats that "this was a uniquely risky and difficult IPO". It's hard to float a company that doesn't have a track record of profitability, for example. Update: he's also making the point that it was a tricky time to float Royal Mail shares, given industrial action at home, and the US debt ceiling crisis abroad. Brian Binley again. He asks Goldman's Cormack whether he thinks the bankers' "intelligence-gathering" activities were exploited by the potential investors who said how much they'd be prepared to pay for Royal Mail. Cormack starts to run through the process again, but is interrupted quickly by Binley, who says: I was in the business of selling beer, years ago. Anyone can sell cheap beer. What i'm suggesting is that you got this wrong, and you should look at your product to that next time you sell a better product to a satisfied customer, Binley adds. Cormack give no indication that Goldman will change its ways: We were seeking a broad-base of long-term investors who would provide broad-based support to the government and give access to the capital markets, he adds. The people who have been buying shares subsequently might not have paid as much in the IPO process. The process we we used was the right one, he insists.… Oh dear, I'm not convinced, says Binley, dropping his pen on the table in disgust. Why didn't UBS and Goldman Sachs spot all the positive newspaper commentary, saying Royal Mail looked undervalued? GS's Cormack replies that the media initially had a balanced view of the IPO, and only turned much more positive in the final days. Did you discount the interest from short-term investors, and what impact did that have? Goldman Sachs' Cormack says that the book-builders did focus on the interests of the long-term shareholders (which Vince Cable wanted to attract), but he don't think this materially affect the value of Royal Mail. What will the Royal Mail share price be in six months time? None of the five investment bankers wants to give a price -- JP Morgan, Citi and Deutsche Bank say they've not been closely involved with the company for six months, having not been chosen to handle the float. UBS's Robertson says there's various factors to consider, including industrial relations and the possibility of VAT being added to postal products. But Panmure's Zonneveld isn't so bashful -- he's got a target price of 570p. And he stands by comments made to the Guardian on October 25th that Royal Mail has good prospects. Is Vince Cable right that the Royal Mail's soaring share price is merely 'froth'"? Most of the bankers say that such early spikes are common. UBS's managing director James Robertson says its "not unusual" to see this kind of thing. But Gert Zonneveld, Managing Director at Panmure Gordon, sinks the very notion of froth. This is not froth....the shares have been trading for six weeks. Markets are quite efficient, he says, adding Today's value is the price that the markets place on it. Brian Binley is back-- accusing the bankers of all defending each other. He suggests that these senior City players are painting a picture of "The cult of the high priest" surrounding the IPO process. Isn't the truth that you simply undervalued Royal Mail, and cost the taxpayer money? Goldman's Cormack doesn't accept this. I feel that we executed the transaction well for the interests of the taxpayer "Well, I wouldn't hire you again," Binley replies. MPs ask the banks who missed out on handling the float how much the government could sell its remaining shares for. How much of a discount would be needed? None will give a clear answer. But Ben Storey, head of UK Investment Banking & Broking at Citibank, says that October's float took place in a "clearly challenging" environment. Market sentiment has improved since, he adds. JP Morgan's John Mayne agrees that some discount would be needed. Tory MP Brian Binley gives Goldman and UBS a serious dressing down. He says that his initial concern was that the government wanted to get a low price to ensure success. "But, now I'm starting to doubt your intelligence-gathering abilities." Your advice and the process you ran has damaged the taxpayer, Binley adds. Goldman Sachs's Richard Cormack defends the banks, saying they had run a "market-led book building process" which had, in his view, successfully delivered a good price. Binley is unimpressed, saying "Someone somewhere has misled the taxpayer and cost the taxpayer." Were you wrong, or did the Secretary of State keep the price low to ensure a successful sale? Cormack replies that: based on all our research, 330p was the price we could achieve for the amount of shares we were selling,says Cormack. For all the money you were paid, you aren't very good at your job, shoots back Binley. Cormack denies it -- saying: This was a large, complicated deal against a difficult backdrop in the markets with the debt ceiling, and the threat of industrial action.... In the context it was a well-execute transaction. Was the US debt ceiling deadlock another factor, as Vince Cable has suggested? Goldman's Cormack says it was -- the London stock market fell for 12 days in a row as investors feared a catastrophic default. It was certainly a factor stopping us raising the IPO price, he adds. But you're a bright man, surely you knew that US politicians would resolve the dilemma. There's always a danger that a deal wouldn't be reached, Cormack adds. UBS's Robertson adds that from September onwards the threat of a Royal Mail strike over pay was the main "risk factor" hanging over the IPO. We've moved onto a key issue -- whether the threat of industrial action pushed down Royal Mail's float price. UBS's James Robertson says that the "appetite" for Royal Mail shares had been coloured by the prospect of a strike. So how much did you change your value by? The strike threat affected the view fo what they theyt were prepare to pay andit set the range of 260 to 330 By how much? It's hard to say. Did you feed this back to Vince Cable? Yes, says Goldman's Cormack. The bankers are asked about Vince Cable's claim in a letter that some large investors had threatened to walk away if the price rose above 330p. Goldman's Cormack confirms these comments. He doesn't know whether those same firms have since bought shares in the stock market (at above 330p, of course) -- but we'll find out eventually when the Royal Mail investor list is updated. Goldman's Cormack says that it was important to sell a majority of Royal Mail shares, and also to retain a large majority for the taxpayer so they can benefit it the share price is higher in the long term. The committee aren't sounding impressed by the process by which the Royal Mail was valued and processed. It sounds like banks are incentivised to pitch the value too low and then drag it up. Goldman's Cormack paints a more positive picture - saying that GS and UBS used the book building process to 'walk people up' from their original lower bids towards the 330p final price. Goldman's Cormack says it takes time for a share price to settle after flotation. UBS's Richardson says there have been eight other IPOs this year in London --- four are trading at least 60% higher than the float, 2 are 25% higher, and 2 are down at least 20%. Goldman Sach's initial pitch for Royal Mail valued it at between £3bn and £3.7bn, later settling on £3.25bn to £3.5bn with a maximum of £3.75bn. UBS's James Robertson says that the Royal Mail should be pleased that much of the shares in the float were sold to "long-term blue chip" investors. He's reminded that a hedge fund, the Children's Investment Fund, has been steadily building a stake in the Royal Mail. Has that pushed the share price up? Robertson says it has. Gert Zonneveld of Panmure Gordon is reminded that Vince Cable dismissed his valuation as an "outlier" when he suggested that Royal Mail might be worth up to £4,5bn in the weeks leading to the float. Is he unhappy about that? Zonneveld plays it cool - saying he's pleased that his research has been vindicated. I"m not concerned about the Secretary of State's comments, he suggests. Chairman Adrian Bailey calls him up on this, saying that sounds like Zonneveld is "deeply concerned". When Vince Cable said he didn't want to rubbish you, well "in political terms it means that he does want to rubbish you", Bailey says. Zonneveld responds: He's a politician, playing politics is what he does. I was the only guy in the market with a view apart from the syndicate banks, he added. Do you accept that you undervalued the company? Goldman's Cormack argues not. He says that you can't expect to sell £2bn of shares, 600m in total, at the same price that just 1.6 million are changing hands today. MPs are keen to find why UBS and Goldman Sachs reckoned Royal Mail was worth less than three other banks - JP Morgan, Citi and Deutsche. James Robertson of UBS says that Royal Mail had no track record of profitability, and faced various risks. Goldman's Richard Cormack says that the valuation at IPO should be divorced from the value at the time of the pitching process. We are all doing outside-in valuation, he says. Panmure's initial valuation was between £4bn and £5bn, but it later settled on a valuation of £3.7bn to £4.5bn, says Gert Zonneveld. Why were the valuations so different? From £3.1bn to over £8bn? Citi's Ben Storey explains that it's actually quite hard to value a company from outside, as you have to make many assumptions. These were preliminary valuations, which can't really be compared to the final floatation value. He says that Citi had a higher expectation for Royal Mail's dividend payment than proved correct. UBS's James Robertson says that it initially valued Royal Mail at £3.1bn, rising to £4.6bn if various risks were resolved. He explains that UBS asked for a base fee of 0.9% of the money raised, plus a 0.3% incentive fee. What is the criteria for getting the bonus fee? Various factors, including the 'after market' performance, and working well with the seller. Is there an incentive for winning banks to pitch a low valuation, and then look successful by getting a higher price? Goldman's Cormack denies it -- the incentive is to get a fair valuation. MPs are getting details from the banks who weren't selected to hold the flotation. And they're pretty interesting. JP Morgan's John Mayne says that it valued Royal Mail at between £6.8bn and £8.5bn Citigroup's Ben Storey says it said valued Royal Mail at between £5.9bn and £6.5bn. Deutsche Bank's James Agnew says it offered a valuation of £5.5bn and £6bn. A reminder -- Royal Mail was sold at a valuation of £3.3bn - and is currently worth around £5.4bn. And what fees did they ask for? It's a complicated answer, as the fees are dependent on the price of the sale. But Citi's valuation would have delivered total fees for all the bankers involved of £14m, and Deutsche's would be £16m. So what was the rational for getting selected? Goldman's Cormack says that it was wide-ranging, including how a bank would pitch the sale to investors, what they valued it at, and how they'd like to be paid. Confirmation that the two banks who got the deal, Goldman and UBS, have received £13m of fees so far. Richard Cormack of Goldman Sachs takes the first question. He explains that the government approached the main investment banks and asked then to pitch. What was the criteria, asks Bailey? An understanding of the company, a track record of handling such sales, and their general competence, Cormack explains. Was there any reason why the government's couldn't hold a Dutch auction? Cormack argues that the approach used was in line with the government's policies, and general City practice. We're underway, with Adrian Bailey asking the six bankers present to explain how the process of becoming an adviser to the float worked.... The BIS committee hearing should start shortly, in the Grimond Room at Portcullis House. It's being streamed live here. On the issue of withholding fees from Goldman Sachs and UBS... they have already received around £12.7m for their work on the Royal Mail float, but there's another £4.2m waiting to be paid at the discretion of the government. Adrian Bailey, the chair of the BIS committee, has already said MPs will examine whether Goldman and UBS will get the outstanding payment. As my colleague Sean Farrell reported on Sunday, Bailey has said: Questions need to be asked about the criteria used to qualify for the deferred payment. Katy Clark, a Labour member of the committee, is keen to find out exactly what the investment banks told the government before it decided the pricing of Royal Mail. Clark said: We want to hear what officials were told. What was the basis on which the advice was provided – and if the asset was worth a huge amount more, was that information given to the secretary of state [Vince Cable] and why wasn't it proceeded on? Cable will appear before the committee next week.... A prediction: MPs will hear that pricing stock market flotations is a devilishly tricky art. Bankers could also cite some high-profile recent IPOs that bombed -- such as Facebook, whose shares sunk when it floated last year (they've rallied hard since, though). As Bloomberg's Caroline Hyde put it: It's a very difficult art to price these floats. In the City, traders often talk about how newly listed companies should 'pop' on their first day's trading. But the problem with using this argument for Royal Mail is that the share have soared by 60% since the float. More a boom than a pop. The Communications Workers Union is calling for the government to withhold outstanding payments to the bankers who advised it on the Royal Mail float. The CWU's general secretary, Billy Hayes, said: Hundreds of millions of pounds of taxpayers' money have been lost because of the failure of the government and its advisers to accurately value the company. In other situations this would be gross incompetence or even theft. Private shareholders have lined their pockets at the expense of the taxpayer following the huge leap in the share price. At the very least the institutions which advised the government should not receive any further payments, which are discretionary. Serious consideration should be given to claiming back fees paid for shoddy advice which has left the client – the taxpayer – out of pocket. I suspect that it won't be possible to claim back those fees already paid - but MPs will raise the issue this morning.... Here's the full story: Royal Mail sale valuation branded a debacle by union Shares in Royal Mail are down 2% this morning, ahead of the BIS committee hearing. They've dropped 11p in early trading to 530p, valuing the company at £5.39bn. That's still 60% higher than the flotation price (in mid-October). This may be triggered by a research note from UBS analysts, who have slapped a 'sell' rating on Royal Mail shares and set a target price of 450p. Something for UBS's managing director, James Robertson, to ponder ahead of his appearance before MPs in an hour's time. Two other analyst houses also published research notes on Royal Mail this morning. Barclays set a target price of 466p, while RBC is more optimistic - it reckons Royal Mail shares are worth 580p. Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of events across the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and the business world. It's rare to see investment bankers called to account for their actions. But today, the top people who advised the government the controversial flotation of Royal Mail face a grilling by MPs. The Business, Investment and Skills committee will demand answers from Goldman Sachs and UBS, who ran the float, on how the postal service was sold off at £3.3bn. It immediately saw its shares soar 38% when trading began last month, and is now valued at over £5bn. The line-up includes JP Morgan -- who apparently told the government during the pricing process that Royal Mail could be worth £10bn -- and Panmure Gordon, the broker who warned that the sale was undervalued. Citi and Deutsche Bank, who also missed out on running the IPO, make up the sextet. The hearing starts at 9.30am. Here's who's attending: John Mayne, Managing Director, UK Client Coverage, JP Morgan Ben Storey, Head of UK Investment Banking & Broking, Citibank Gert Zonneveld, Managing Director, Co-Head of Research, Panmure Gordon James Agnew, Chairman of UK Corporate Broking, Deutsche Bank James Robertson, Managing Director, UBS Richard Cormack, Managing Director, Co-Head of Equity Capital Markets, Goldman Sachs Royal Mail's not the only story in town, though. The Co-op Group remains in the news for the wrong reasons, as the scandal around former Bank chairman Paul Flowers swirls. Police search home of former Co-op Bank boss. We'll also be looking at central banks, with the publication of the latest Bank of England minutes at 9.30am GMT (just as the Royal Mail hearing starts...). They'll give an insight into how the Monetary Policy Committee sees the UK economy (the BoE was pretty upbeat at last week's quarterly inflation report). The US Federal Reserve is also releasing its latest minutes tonight, but the markets have already got a large dollop of wisdom from its outgoing chair, Ben Bernanke, to digest. Overnight, he declared that the Fed was committed to ultra-loose monetary policy for as long as needed -- suggesting no early tightening of its huge stimulus programme. Despite this promise of yet more easy money, Europe's stock markets are expected to slide this morning. Trading has begun, with the FTSE 100 is down 0.4%, or 21 points, at 6670. And we'll also be watching Greece, where talks between the government and its troika of lenders appear to be gummed down. I'll be tracking all the action through the day....

webTitle: UK's biggest outsourcing firms agree to more public scrutiny

fields.standfirst: G4S, Serco, Atos and Capita, which have £4bn of government contracts, say they will allow auditors to access their books
fields.body:
Britain's four biggest outsourcing companies have agreed to respond to demands for greater transparency by allowing the government's auditors access to their books and giving greater leeway to freedom of information requests.

Executives from G4S, Serco, Atos and Capita, whose firms operate £4bn worth of government contracts, agreed that they should come under further scrutiny from auditors and members of the public.

The concessions, at a session before the public accounts committee, follow months of discussions between committee members and the government over how to increase scrutiny of outsourcing companies to ensure proper spending of the public pound.

At the meeting, the G4S chief executive, Ashley Almanza, also admitted the company had failed to "tell the difference between right and wrong" when dealing with its electronic monitoring contracts. The Serco chairman, Alistair Lyons, said it was "ethically wrong" that his company had also overcharged the Ministry of Justice.

The Serious Fraud Office (SFO) opened a criminal investigation after it emerged that G4S and Serco had overcharged the government for tagging offenders, some of whom were found to be dead, back in prison or overseas.

Almanza surprised some committee members when he said the Olympics contract was, by and large, a success.

"We delivered 80% of the Olympics contract, and paid a fine of £88m, and delivered all of the security for the Paralympics," he said.

webTitle: Royal Mail float: paying bankers' deferred fees would be 'mad', MP says

fields.bodyText: The government would be "mad" to pay more than £4m in deferred fees to the banks that advised on Royal Mail's privatisation because they undervalued the company, the chairman of a parliamentary committee said after grilling the bankers on Wednesday. Adrian Bailey, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (Bis) select committee, said paying the fees, on top of more than £12m already handed over, would reward highly paid bankers who set the float price too low at the expense of the taxpayer. Bailey gave his judgment after the committee questioned senior staff from Goldman Sachs and UBS, the banks that led the flotation. In more than two hours of questioning, they were accused of failing at their jobs and selling the taxpayer short. The government sold 60% of Royal Mail at 330p a share last month, valuing the company at £3.3bn. But the shares leapt 38% on their first day of trading and closed on Wednesday at 550p, giving Royal Mail a market value of £5.5bn. Goldman, UBS and five other banks that marketed the shares have so far been paid £12.7m between them but they could get a further £4.2m if Vince Cable, the secretary of state, thinks they warrant it. Bailey said: "The government, in view of what has happened subsequently, would be mad to give them [the money]. "It would be seen as rewarding the private sector that lost the taxpayer potentially £1bn and, in these days of austerity, I think it would be a very politically dangerous thing to do. These are professional people, who got it wrong, and they would be rewarded despite the fact they got it wrong." The banks in the syndicate that marketed Royal Mail to investors shared fees of 0.8% of the money raised, with Goldman and UBS splitting an extra 0.1% for leading the operation. The government's independent adviser, Lazard, has been paid £1.5m with no fees deferred. Asked whether taxpayers would be willing to accept the banks getting the extra fees, UBS's James Robertson said: "I think that is for the secretary of state to decide. It is in his gift." MPs questioned James Robertson and Richard Cormack of Goldman Sachs alongside bankers from Citi, JP Morgan and Deutsche Bank, which missed out on advising on the float. Gert Zonneveld of Panmure Gordon, who argued that Royal Mail was undervalued before the shares started trading, also appeared. Goldman's initial pitch, made without inside information, valued Royal Mail at up to £3.75bn and UBS's top estimate was £4.6bn. The others were more than £1bn higher with JP Morgan's the highest at £8.5bn. The banks' job was to sound out fund managers on how much they were prepared to pay for the shares and to generate demand in a so-called book-building process. As interest increased, they moved the price to the top of their initial 260p-330p range. The UBS and Goldman bankers defended the sale price, saying a potential US debt default and the threat of a nationwide postal strike loomed over the flotation. Robertson admitted the government could have got a further 20p per share if it had gone above the agreed range but he said the risks were too great because it would have caused a delay and pushed long-term investors to their limit. "Momentum can evaporate and go away very quickly … when we were looking at all the risks, on balance we chose to stick to 330p. We discussed it with the Shareholder Executive [which advises on privatisations] and Lazard and they discussed it with the secretary of state." But committee members accused the banks of failing at their job and of being duped by potential investors, who always want to pay as little as possible. Brian Binley, a Conservative member of the committee, told the bankers: "Somebody somewhere has failed the taxpayer and cost the taxpayer in this initial instance. I just wonder whether the taxpayer has the right to wonder whether for all the money you were paid you weren't very good at your job." The committee's attention will now turn to Cable and his minister Michael Fallon, who will appear next Wednesday with representatives from Lazard and the Shareholder Executive. In his last appearance at the committee just before the flotation, Cable dismissed the prospect of a jump in Royal Mail's share price as "froth". Bailey said the session with the bankers was preparation for asking Cable why he priced the privatisation so low. "I think there was a recognition [by the committee] that the price has been undervalued. Did they rate their political position as being more important than the interests of the taxpayer because if it was overpriced they would have had egg on their faces?" A spokesman for the Bis department declined to comment. What they said "I'm hearing an awful lot of sales speak and an awful lot of stuff from you all about how wonderful you are, what superb backup and what great expertise you have. You have all come together like a professional body to defend each other. Can I, as a taxpayer, assume that all this is the cult of the high priest and [is] meant to be exclusive and keep others out and meant to say you are much better at your job than you are, and you have failed the tax payer?" Brian Binley, Conservative committee member "We advised the government we could get an extra 20p above the 330p before demand from long-term investors would have fallen off very sharply. We considered that very carefully because obviously 20p is a lot of money … This was a uniquely difficult and risky IPO and there will be lessons learnt from how to execute these in the future." James Robertson, UBS "The average [trading] volume at the moment on a daily basis of these shares is about 1.3 million shares versus the 600m shares that we placed at the time of the IPO. I don't think that today's price is indicative of where we could have placed 600m shares." Richard Cormack, Goldman Sachs "I do not think it [the current Royal Mail share price] is froth. These shares have been trading on the market for nearly six weeks, several hundred million shares have traded hands. Today's value of the company is the value that the market attributes to it." Gert Zonneveld, Panmure Gordon "The question we want to pursue further is, what advice was given to the government, and in effect how much influence the government brought upon Goldman Sachs and UBS to determine the price level, and how much was genuinely feedback from the market? Or were Goldman and UBS misled [by investors]?" Adrian Bailey, committee chairman

fields.headline: Royal Mail float: paying bankers' deferred fees would be 'mad', MP says
fields.body:
The government would be "mad" to pay more than £4m in deferred fees to the banks that advised on Royal Mail's privatisation because they undervalued the company, the chairman of a parliamentary committee said after grilling the bankers on Wednesday.

Adrian Bailey, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (Bis) select committee, said paying the fees, on top of more than £12m already handed over, would reward highly paid bankers who set the float price too low at the expense of the taxpayer.

Bailey gave his judgment after the committee questioned senior staff from Goldman Sachs and UBS, the banks that led the flotation. In more than two hours of questioning, they were accused of failing at their jobs and selling the taxpayer short.

The government sold 60% of Royal Mail at 330p a share last month, valuing the company at £3.3bn. But the shares leapt 38% on their first day of trading and closed on Wednesday at 550p, giving Royal Mail a market value of £5.5bn.

Goldman, UBS and five other banks that marketed the shares have so far been paid £12.7m between them but they could get a further £4.2m if Vince Cable, the secretary of state, thinks they warrant it.

Bailey said: "The government, in view of what has happened subsequently, would be mad to give them [the money].

"It would be seen as rewarding the private sector that lost the taxpayer potentially £1bn and, in these days of austerity, I think it would be a very politically dangerous thing to do. These are professional people, who got it wrong, and they would be rewarded despite the fact they got it wrong."

The banks in the syndicate that marketed Royal Mail to investors shared fees of 0.8% of the money raised, with Goldman and UBS splitting an extra 0.1% for leading the operation. The government's independent adviser, Lazard, has been paid £1.5m with no fees deferred.

Asked whether taxpayers would be willing to accept the banks getting the extra fees, UBS's James Robertson said: "I think that is for the secretary of state to decide. It is in his gift."

MPs questioned James Robertson and Richard Cormack of Goldman Sachs alongside bankers from Citi, JP Morgan and Deutsche Bank, which missed out on advising on the float. Gert Zonneveld of Panmure Gordon, who argued that Royal Mail was undervalued before the shares started trading, also appeared.

Goldman's initial pitch, made without inside information, valued Royal Mail at up to £3.75bn and UBS's top estimate was £4.6bn. The others were more than £1bn higher with JP Morgan's the highest at £8.5bn.

The banks' job was to sound out fund managers on how much they were prepared to pay for the shares and to generate demand in a so-called book-building process. As interest increased, they moved the price to the top of their initial 260p-330p range.

The UBS and Goldman bankers defended the sale price, saying a potential US debt default and the threat of a nationwide postal strike loomed over the flotation.

Robertson admitted the government could have got a further 20p per share if it had gone above the agreed range but he said the risks were too great because it would have caused a delay and pushed long-term investors to their limit. "Momentum can evaporate and go away very quickly … when we were looking at all the risks, on balance we chose to stick to 330p. We discussed it with the Shareholder Executive [which advises on privatisations] and Lazard and they discussed it with the secretary of state."

But committee members accused the banks of failing at their job and of being duped by potential investors, who always want to pay as little as possible.

Brian Binley, a Conservative member of the committee, told the bankers: "Somebody somewhere has failed the taxpayer and cost the taxpayer in this initial instance. I just wonder whether the taxpayer has the right to wonder whether for all the money you were paid you weren't very good at your job."

The committee's attention will now turn to Cable and his minister Michael Fallon, who will appear next Wednesday with representatives from Lazard and the Shareholder Executive. In his last appearance at the committee just before the flotation, Cable dismissed the prospect of a jump in Royal Mail's share price as "froth".

Bailey said the session with the bankers was preparation for asking Cable why he priced the privatisation so low.

"I think there was a recognition [by the committee] that the price has been undervalued. Did they rate their political position as being more important than the interests of the taxpayer because if it was overpriced they would have had egg on their faces?"

A spokesman for the Bis department declined to comment.

What they said

"I'm hearing an awful lot of sales speak and an awful lot of stuff from you all about how wonderful you are, what superb backup and what great expertise you have. You have all come together like a professional body to defend each other. Can I, as a taxpayer, assume that all this is the cult of the high priest and [is] meant to be exclusive and keep others out and meant to say you are much better at your job than you are, and you have failed the tax payer?" Brian Binley, Conservative committee member

"We advised the government we could get an extra 20p above the 330p before demand from long-term investors would have fallen off very sharply. We considered that very carefully because obviously 20p is a lot of money … This was a uniquely difficult and risky IPO and there will be lessons learnt from how to execute these in the future." James Robertson, UBS

"The average [trading] volume at the moment on a daily basis of these shares is about 1.3 million shares versus the 600m shares that we placed at the time of the IPO. I don't think that today's price is indicative of where we could have placed 600m shares." Richard Cormack, Goldman Sachs

"I do not think it [the current Royal Mail share price] is froth. These shares have been trading on the market for nearly six weeks, several hundred million shares have traded hands. Today's value of the company is the value that the market attributes to it." Gert Zonneveld, Panmure Gordon

"The question we want to pursue further is, what advice was given to the government, and in effect how much influence the government brought upon Goldman Sachs and UBS to determine the price level, and how much was genuinely feedback from the market? Or were Goldman and UBS misled [by investors]?" Adrian Bailey, committee chairman

webTitle: Co-operative Bank scandal: bring on the inquiry, but it must be independent

fields.standfirst: The saga is an embarrassment for the Co-operative movement, UK financial regulation and – perhaps – politicians of all main parties
fields.body:
Launching an independent inquiry into the near-failure of the Co-op Bank would have been the right thing to do even before the exciting life of Rev Paul Flowers, the bank's former chairman, provided entertainment for the nation.

The catastrophe has happened in an era of supposed get-tough regulation and better governance in boardrooms. The saga is an embarrassment for the Co-operative movement, UK financial regulation and – perhaps – politicians of all main parties who cheered a bank that was unworthy of their support. So, yes, best to get to the bottom of what went wrong.

But two provisos have to made. First, the timing of its launch is dangerous to the short-term ambition of saving the Co-op Bank and filling the £1.5bn capital hole. The would-be rescuers – bondholders led by a couple of US hedge funds – could develop cold feet. It is unclear what rights they have to withdraw or renegotiate terms but it is obvious that the Co-op Bank shares they were so keen to obtain will be damaged by the "Flowers factor". An inquiry backed by the prime minister will raise the stakes another notch.

Second, if you are going to hold an inquiry make sure it is properly independent. That means ensuring the front-line regulators are kept out of the picture since the most pressing questions relate to them: the former Financial Services Authority, now remodelled as the Financial Conduct Authority and Prudential Regulation Authority. Why did the FSA approve the inexperienced Flowers in the first place? Why did the regulator leave him in place? What checks were made on other Co-op Bank directors? Why was the Co-op allowed to proceed so long with its failed attempt to buy 630 Verde branches from Lloyds even though it was blindingly obvious to the outside world that the bank was struggling to walk, let alone run? And, in a similar situation in future, would the split responsibilities of the FCA and the PRA prove a help or hindrance?

"It is essential that we establish that the FCA and PRA are properly co-ordinating," says Lord Myners, City minister in the last Labour government. "For a review to be credible in establishing confidence in their procedures, it would have to be conducted by somebody outside either of those organisations." Quite right: an independent inquiry has to mean what it says.

David Cameron may also be hoping an inquiry will be embarrassing for Labour. It may be. But we are also told (not just by the disgraced Flowers) that current Treasury minister Mark Hoban held 30 meetings or telephone conversations with Co-op Bank executives during the Verde saga. Why did Hoban invest so much of his time? And did he think governance at the bank was up to scratch?

The Treasury select committee has looked under a few stones already. Now it's time for a full excavation.

Royal Mail float
Investment bankers closed ranks in front of MPs

It was a light toasting, rather than a grilling. The bankers from Goldman Sachs and UBS insisted they did everything thoroughly and properly in floating Royal Mail. They conceded the price could have squeezed higher by 20p-a-share but said such a move would have come with risks.

And the upright chaps from JP Morgan, Citigroup and Deutsche, who had all thought the postal service could be worth a few more billions when pitching for the advisory gig, declined to put the boot into their supposed rivals. They said there was a world of difference between their own "desktop" valuations and the price established by demand by real sellers in a sale they agreed was terribly complicated.

It was an unsatisfactory hearing at the business select committee. The investment banking industry closed ranks; as Tory MP Brian Binley put it, the "cult of the high priest" reigned. Poor old taxpayers (or those without Royal Mail shares) are still bewildered as to how a sale at 330p can be a success if the shares shoot to 550p. To get a different point of view MPs should summon Chris Hohn from hedge fund TCI. He's the fellow, who has bought 5.8% of Royal Mail. Where does he see the value?

The hunch here is that the clue to solving the great Royal Mail mystery lies in the dividend as this is a yield stock. The company has said it will pay the equivalent of £200m this year but has provided little detail as to how the figure was derived. The banks with high valuations had been expecting to see a far more generous distribution. So did the Royal Mail err on the side of deep conservatism in setting its first dividend? Any thoughts, Mr Hohn?

webTitle: Two inquiries launched into Co-op Bank and ex-chairman Paul Flowers

fields.standfirst: Government announces investigations into bank after former chairman is filmed allegedly buying hard drugs
fields.body:
The government is to launch two independent inquiries into the demise of the Co-operative Bank and the embarrassing revelations about its former chairman, Paul Flowers.

The prime minister described Flowers as the "man who has broken a bank" following questions about his financial competence, drug-taking and resignation as a Bradford councillor over adult material on his computer.

There will be an inquiry by the Financial Conduct Authority into the behaviour of key individuals, as well as a separate more general inquiry ordered by the chancellor, George Osborne, which will be conducted by the Prudential Regulation Authority.

These inquiries are separate to a police inquiry, the investigation under way by the Treasury select committee and an internal inquiry already ordered by the Co-op Group headed by Sir Christopher Kelly, the former chairman of the committee on standards in public life.

The decision to launch the two official inquiries is likely to be announced next week, and the precise format, including whether evidence will be taken in public, has yet to be decided.

Downing Street is confident that David Cameron's decision to refer to the possible inquiries will not destabilise the already perilous position of the Co-op Bank, since the two American Hedge Funds effectively running the bank are committed to putting £125m into it.

To an extent the inquiry into how the Co-op Bank came to find itself in such a mess will also be another inquiry into a discredited supervisory system headed by the now defunct Financial Services Authority (FSA).

It is also likely to look into whether the FSA should have realised that the Co-op Bank takeover of the Britannia in 2009 was never advisable. It may also look to see if there was any political encouragement for this takeover by the Treasury under the control of Alistair Darling or by the then prime minister, Gordon Brown.

David Anderson, the former chief executive of the Co-operative Bank at the time of the merger with its rival Britannia building society, told the Treasury select committee this week that there had been no political involvement.

Anderson, who stepped down in July 2009, told MPs that Britannia's bad real-estate loans "did not bring down the bank".

In a boisterous session of prime minister's questions on Wednesday, Cameron raised questions over Flowers's suitability to run the bank. He claimed Labour must have known about the bank chairman's past when his appointment was approved by regulators under the last government.

Police have searched the home of Flowers, a Methodist minister who led the bank for three years, after he was filmed allegedly buying and using hard drugs including crystal meth, crack cocaine and ketamine.

The Co-op Bank's merger with Britannia and taking on its bad property loans was blamed in part for the £1.5bn capital shortfall revealed at the bank earlier this year. Co-op party sources insist they had no control over the conduct of the Co-op Bank and say Flowers's position as chairman of the Co-op Bank was largely titular.

The FCA inquiry will also look into how the FSA interviewed Flowers and agreed that he could be promoted from non-executive director to chairman.

The Methodist church, which suspended Flowers for three weeks on Sunday when the video of his drug purchases emerged, has now extended that exclusion.

"The Rev Paul Flowers has now been suspended indefinitely as part of our complaints and discipline process. This replaces his earlier suspension. We always wait for any police investigation or court proceedings to conclude before moving forward with the complaints process, and so there will be no further action until then. Paul is being offered pastoral care, and we ask for prayers for all involved in this matter," a spokesman said.

webTitle: RWE npower supply sale raises fears over UK withdrawal

fields.standfirst: Industry expert with close links to RWE npower said the utility would make further cuts in the face of 'huge uncertainty in Germany and Britain'
fields.body:
There were mounting concerns on Wednesday that RWE npower, one of the big six energy providers, will unveil further disinvestments in Britain following the sale for £218m of a supply business with half a million customers.

RWE disposed of its £350m stake in the Horizon nuclear power venture in the UK last year and is searching for a buyer for its DEA oil exploration arm, operator of 13 producing gas fields in the North Sea.

The power group needs to raise and save cash due to a decision by the German government to boost renewable power and phase out nuclear plants, but it is also reacting to growing political risk in Britain.

The Essen-based company declined to comment on further cutbacks but an industry expert with close links to RWE npower said the utility would make further cuts in the face of "huge uncertainty in Germany and Britain" that made raising money very difficult for energy projects.

The expert, who asked not to be named, said the combination of coalition government dithering over the Energy Market Reform bill compounded by Ed Miliband's retail price freeze had unnerved RWE at a time when it wanted to cut 6,750 jobs worldwide by 2016 and was struggling with £30bn worth of debt.

Npower, which has just raised its gas and electricity prices by 10.4% and come under fire for poor service plus low tax payments, on Wednesday agreed to sell two gas and electricity subsidiaries to Telecom Plus, a smaller supplier of energy and telephone services that trades as Utility Warehouse.

Npower – named this week as the energy firm with the highest number of consumer complaints and currently beset by central computer failures – promised that customers would see no negative change in their service or contracts.

Last month npower was among the energy companies hauled before the energy select committee, to face MPs' accusations that they offered a confusing array of tariffs that allowed them to make "unfair profits". The showdown reflected growing concern that the energy market is not working properly, in the wake of Labour leader Miliband's call for a price freeze.

Paul Massara, the chief executive of npower, said the sale would be good for competition. "In one move we have helped to create the biggest independent competitor in Britain's household energy supply market. This is good for competition and good for consumer choice. Today's announcement shows that Britain is well on the way to having a big seven rather than a big six."

He added: "This shows that there is a willingness to compete in Britain's energy market, and that the market is anything but broken."

Adam Scorer, director of customer watchdog, Consumer Futures, agreed with Massara that further competition could only be helpful. "We're pleased that Telecom Plus has reached an agreement with Npower that will enable it to continue competing in the energy supply market. Their brand Utility Warehouse is the biggest multi-utility provider in the market and it is welcome they can continue to provide much needed competition for the big six," he said.

The 500,000 customers already have (around 770,000) accounts with Utility Warehouse, which supplies them with a combined package of gas, electricity, landline and broadband services. Until now, npower has been responsible for supplying the energy part of the bundle on a wholesale basis under a deal it struck with Telecom Plus/Utility Warehouse in 2006.

The decision to sell these accounts followed an Ofgem market review where the regulator called for a clearer, simpler energy market. An npower spokesman described the sale as "a useful deal" that clarified formal responsibility for these customers.

Npower will retain a significant interest and will continue to supply electricity and gas to the subsidiaries being sold for the next 20 years.

Charles Wigoder, chairman of Telecom Plus, said it was "a transformational deal for the company, delivering significant earnings enhancement".

The company, whose sales practices have been heavily criticised in the past, aims to get 1m households to sign up to their utility bundle of energy and telecoms services in the coming years. Npower said it expected to complete the deal in late December or early January.

webTitle: Reinhart and Rogoff's latest paper warns on financial repression

fields.standfirst: Harvard duo argue that advanced countries will not be able to return to more sustainable levels of debt through austerity and growth
fields.body:
For Carmen Reinhart and Ken Rogoff, 2013 has been a year to forget. The big news in the world of academic economics was that a celebrated and hugely influential paper by the Harvard duo on the link between government debt and growth was wrong. The paper, cited regularly by supporters of austerity programmes, said countries where the national debt was higher than 90% of national output (GDP) could expect to see a marked drop off in growth. On examination, the data used by Reinhart and Rogoff showed there was no such link, with the pair's (many) critics saying that the line of causality lies in the opposite direction: low growth leads to high levels of debt rather than high debt leading to low growth.

R and R continue to churn out papers in their chosen field, the latest of which has just been published by the London-based Centre for Economic Policy Research. The study – Financial and sovereign debt crises: some lessons learned and those forgotten – is no less incendiary than their now infamous "Growth in a time of debt".

Why? Because Reinhart and Rogoff say that if history is any guide countries will not be able to return to more sustainable levels of public debt through a combination of austerity and growth. They cite Europe, where the assumption is that normality can be restored by a combination of belt-tightening, forbearance and rising output, as an example of Panglossian thinking.

"The claim is that advanced countries do not need to apply the standard toolkit used by emerging markets, including debt restructurings, higher inflation, capital controls and significant financial repression. Advanced countries do not resort to such gimmicks, policy makers say."

Historically, this is poppycock according to Reinhart and Rogoff. Rich countries, when faced with high levels of debt in the past have been more than happy to default, inflate away their debts or indulge in financial repression (capping interest rates or putting pressure on savers to lend to the government).

The paper veers close to the contested territory of "Growth in a time of debt" when it says that debt overhangs of the sort affecting advanced countries are typically associated with a sustained period of sub-par growth, lasting two decades or more. That was certainly the case in the aftermath of the first world war, when austerity was much in vogue, but not after the second world war, which was followed by the longest uninterrupted period of growth the west has ever experienced.

It is true, however, that many advanced countries – including Britain and France – welched during the Great Depression on their debts to the United States amassed between 1914 and 1918. After the second world war, financial repression was the weapon of choice for heavily indebted countries. They capped interest payments by keeping interest rates low and used capital controls to prevent money from leaving the country. Given the tight curbs on capital, it is no coincidence that the "financial repression" period of 1945-79 had far fewer crises than earlier or subsequently.

Reinhart and Rogoff say that central government debt is "approaching a two century high" in advanced countries and – even leaving to one side off-balance liabilities such as the cost of paying for ageing populations – and is unlikely to be cured by growth alone. Governments, they say, may need to revert to approaches "that have long been associated with emerging markets and that advanced countries themselves once practised not so long ago."

The reality is that many governments are already doing just that. webTitle: Gold miners slide as FTSE 100 cautious ahead of Federal Reserve minutes

fields.standfirst: Investors await latest views from central bank on further economic stimulus
fields.body:
Gold was on the slide again, pushing shares in precious metal mining companies sharply lower.

Amid uncertain trading on stock markets ahead of the release of the latest US Federal Reserve minutes - which will be scoured for signs of the central bank's view on future economic stimulus - Randgold Resources lost 126p to £44.95, making it the biggest faller in the leading index.

African Barrick Gold dropped 10.7p to 181p and Fresnillo fell 9p to 904.5p. Michael Hewson at CMC Markets said:

Gold has been a big slider today.... which suggests that the weak or benign inflation outlook is curbing demand for the precious metal. This afternoon's weak inflation reading from the US tends to reinforce this weak outlook. While inflation remains capped, the outlook for the yellow metal seems likely to remain weak irrespective of whether the Fed minutes are hawkish or dovish.

Ahead of the Fed minutes, St Louis Fed president James Bullard suggested the central bank might still look at easing back on its $85bn a month bond buying programme at its December meeting. He said a strong jobs figure for November would increase the prospect of tapering. Markets have been dominated by trying to work out when the Fed would turn off the money taps, but most observers believe it will not act until next year.

Meanwhile there were reports revisiting the idea that the European Central Bank might consider a negative deposit rate to boost growth, which sent the euro lower.

The Bank of England's latest minutes also suggested there would be no quick interest rate rise in the UK.

Overall, the FTSE 100 finished 16.93 points lower at 6681.08.

Vodafone - tipped this week once more as a bid target - was among the fallers, down 4.85p to 227.2p as its shares were ex-dividend.

Drinks group Diageo dipped 23.5p to £20.05 after an investor day on Tuesday, in which it moved away from its previous stance of giving forward guidance. Mike Dennis at Cantor Fitzgerald said:

Our overall take was that the outlook was for less top-line sales growth (below the 5%-8% net sales growth range and more price than volume) and less margin gains versus 2012 and 2013. Diageo is facing less predictable growth patterns in Emerging Markets as GDP growth rates slow and, sales of their largest spirit brand, Smirnoff Vodka, slow too.

Building materials group Wolseley, which has a strong presence in the US, slipped 21p to £32.29 after the American Institute of Architects' Architecture Billings Index fell to 51.6 in October after hitting a seven-month high of 54.3 in September.

But Aberdeen Asset Management moved higher in the wake of this week's £660m acquisition of Scottish Widows from Lloyds Banking Group. It added 16.8p to 492p as Barclays and Berenberg both raised their price targets.

EasyJet jumped another 32p to £13.77 after its well received results.

GlaxoSmithKline moved 3.5p higher to 1631.5p after raising £425m by selling part of its stake in South African drugmaker Aspen Pharmacare.

Glaxo disposed of 28.2m shares in Aspen, leaving it with 12.4% of the business. It will retain a seat on the board of the business and has agreed not to sell any further shares for at least six months.

Among the mid-caps, engineering group Kentz Corporation climbed 13p to 555p after it won a $190m contract from Qatar Petroleum for industrial control systems for around 775 wells of the Dukhan oilfield in the middle east.

On the day MPs quizzed bankers over the Royal Mail flotation price, the company was steady at 550p. as a stream of City research was released. Analysts at UBS - which was one of the banks up before the select committee - issued a sell note with a 450p price target. Barclays was also negative, with an equal weight rating and a 466p price target.

Meanwhile rival UK Mail jumped 30p to 615p after half year profits rose 63% to £11.9m, boosted by a strong performance from its parcels business.

Dixons Retail impressed analysts after showing off its new Currys PC World store in Aylesbury and its shares added 0.62p to 49.02p.

Finally Bonmarché, the value retailer, began life on Aim with a 20.5p increase on the 200p issue price.

webTitle: The Co-op Bank saga needs answers – but don't hold your breath | Jill Treanor

fields.standfirst: George Osborne is to talk to regulators about a full-scale inquiry into how the supposedly staid and responsible co-operative ended up with £1.5bn capital shortfall
fields.body:
David Cameron has finally announced to MPs that the chancellor is to have discussions with regulators about launching a full-scale inquiry into what has gone wrong at Co-operative Bank.

It has taken lurid details of the private life of the bank's former chairman to prompt George Osborne to start talks about an independent investigation into how a supposedly staid and responsible co-operative ended up with a £1.5bn capital shortfall.

The prospect of embarrassing the Labour front bench undoubtedly played a part in the timing of the prime minister's announcement. Paul Flowers, the former Co-op chairman filmed handing over cash to buy drugs, has met both Ed Miliband and Ed Balls. He is a member – now suspended – of the Labour party and the Co-op Bank extended a new £1.2m loan in April, weeks after a meeting between Flowers and Miliband.

But Flowers has told of other political connections, including meeting Conservative MP Owen Paterson, then secretary of state for Northern Ireland, in a Hyatt Hotel room at the Tory party conference shortly after the election to talk about a possible rescue of a failing mutual society – the Presbyterian – later bailed out with £200m.

The near-collapse of the Co-op Bank – which should have been thriving on its mutuality in the wake of the banking crisis – needs to be investigated to establish whether it was mistakes made by its management and regulators that left it with such a sudden gaping hole its finances.

The inquiry is expected to go back to 2009, which will enable it to investigate the Co-op Bank's merger with Britannia Building Society at the height of the financial crisis – a move which has since proved disastrous.

It should also look in detail at how the Co-op's talks to take over 631 branches from bailed-out Lloyds Banking Group ended in tatters – and with a £300m bill to cover the costs of its own IT systems, which had been left to rot on the assumption that the Lloyds deal would bring more sophisticated systems along with it.

The negotiations for that deal took place on the coalition's watch, with Osborne, Cable et al hopeful that an enlarged Co-op Bank could become a serious new competitor on the high street.

The whole Co-op saga presents many questions that need answers, but quick explanations seem unlikely.

First, a police inquiry into the allegations of drug-buying will need to be completed. Then the Financial Conduct Authority must decide whether to take enforcement action against the bank and any of its directors. Only then could an independent inquiry get under way, most likely commissioned by the FCA or the Bank of England's Prudential Regulation Authority.

And that will take time. Five years after the collapse of HBOS a regulatory report on what went wrong inside that bank has yet to see the light of day.

webTitle: Royal Mail shares dip as flotation advisor's analysts issue sell note

fields.standfirst: UBS analyst put 450p price target on business and say market is overestimating outlook
fields.body:
On the day MPs quizzed bankers over the Royal Mail flotation price, the company's shares have fallen 1.5% as a stream of City research was released. Analysts at UBS - which was one of the banks up before the select committee - issued a sell note with a 450p price target. UBS said:

We believe management has executed well on improving productivity, with the UK margin rising to 4.3% in 2012-2013 from -1.6% in 2009-10. We expect further improvements, due to productivity and revenue growth. However, with Royal Mail's share price up 69% since the IPO (versus 7%-32% for peers), we believe the market is over-estimating margin upside. In particular, we believe it will be difficult to accelerate its transformation, given the limitations of the labour agreement. To get to the upper end of the 5-10% regulated range (assumed by the market; current 3%) would require acceleration of staff reductions, additional automation and no adverse events.

Barclays was also negative, although it shied away from a sell recommendation despite a target price some 16% below the level when the bank's note was issued. Barclays said:

Following milestone regulatory changes and a landmark pension agreement, Royal Mail Group is, in our view, set to benefit from: a) price flexibility, mitigating the impact of letter volume decline; 2) parcel volume growth, driven by rising online retail penetration and economic recovery; and 3) efficiency improvements and cost-containment potential. We forecast earnings per share compound annual growth rate of 21% over the next four years and robust free cash flow generation, allowing for aggressive deleveraging and a competitive dividend policy. However, following the share price performance since its listing, we believe the stock fully reflects the group's strong prospects. We therefore initiate coverage with an equal weight rating and a 466p price target.

At Investec, analyst John Lawson said:

Royal Mail is undergoing one of the UK's largest business transformation programmes witnessed in recent years and, provided that the group can continue to retain the support of its employees, this 'self-help' programme should be a powerful driver of earnings growth and cash going forward. Change is needed (not least because the letters business is in structural decline). The stock has started well and, whilst it might pause for breath, next week's interims (27 November) will be keenly watched. We start at hold.

But Shore Capital was more positive, issuing a buy note, with analyst Robin Speakman saying:

We believe that a significant opportunity exists for growth, leveraging change in social behaviour and driven by the internet and e-commerce, provided that Royal Mail continues to evolve and attack this change head on. We note that industrial action, whilst rightly feared, has remained in the background throughout the business's major transformation in recent years.
Much has been made of latent value inherent in the business. Whilst we can see the argument on property valuation, for example, we are sceptical that this is set to provide material upside to the current valuation. In sum, we see long-term opportunity and so take a long-term view of the investment potential.

Royal Mail is down 8.5p at 541.5p, still well above the controversial 330p flotation price of course.

Meanwhile rival UK Mail has jumped more than 6% to 622p after half year profits rose 63% to £11.9m, boosted by a strong performance from its parcels business.

webTitle: David Cameron: inquiry into Co-op Bank may be needed

fields.standfirst: PM raises questions over ex-chairman Paul Flowers's role, saying Labour must have known of his past
fields.body:
David Cameron has raised the prospect of an inquiry into the Co-op Bank over its financial struggles and embarrassing revelations about its former chairman, Paul Flowers.

The prime minister described Flowers as the "man who has broken a bank" following questions about his financial competence, drug-taking and resignation as a Bradford councillor over adult material on his computer.

It comes after the Co-op Bank – traditionally an ethical mutual – hit serious financial difficulties and had to be bailed out by the US hedge funds that owned its debt.

In a boisterous session of prime minister's questions, Cameron raised questions over Flowers's suitability to run the bank. He claimed Labour must have known about the bank chairman's past when his appointment was approved by regulators under the last government.

"The chancellor will be discussing with the regulators what is the appropriate form of inquiry to get to the bottom of what went wrong here," he said.

"But there are clearly a lot of questions that have to be answered. Why was Rev Flowers judged suitable to be chairman of a bank? Why weren't alarm bells ringing earlier, particularly by those who knew?

"I think it will be important in the coming days that if anyone does have information they stand up and provide it to the authorities."

Cameron's comments raise the prospect of the government using its new powers, introduced in 2012 in the wake of the 2008 banking crisis, to force a regulator to conduct an inquiry.

It would be expected to pre-date 2012 and might even cover the period back to 2009 when the Co-op merged with the Britannia Building Society.

Three potential options are up for consideration – a criminal inquiry, which West Yorkshire police have already indicated they are considering, inquiries by the two City regulators – the Prudential Regulation Authority and the Financial Conduct Authority – which the coalition created last year, and an independent-style inquiry which would in all likelihood only take place once the other inquiries had run their course.

None of the investigations into the near collapse of banks during the 2008 crisis have been independent. The City regulator at the time, the Financial Services Authority, launched its own review into what went wrong at Royal Bank of Scotland, while publication of a review into why HBOS collapsed has yet to be published more than five years after the bank was rescued by Lloyds Banking Group.

The coalition could task the new regulatory bodies to conduct an inquiry into the collapse of the Co-op and appoint an individual to oversee any inquiry. A decision is yet to be made on what form any inquiry could take.

In the Commons Cameron put pressure on Miliband over Labour's links with the Co-op Bank after it emerged that donations and loans of more than £1m from the struggling financial institution had increased under Flowers's chairmanship.

"What we can now see is that this bank, driven into the wall by this chairman, has been giving soft loans to the Labour party, facilities to the Labour party, donations to the Labour party, trooped in and out of Downing Street under Labour, still advising the leader of the Labour party," he said.

"And yet, now we know, all along they knew about his past. Why did they do nothing to bring to the attention of the authorities this man who has broken a bank?"

Police have searched the home of Flowers, a Methodist minister who led the bank for three years, after he was filmed allegedly buying and using hard drugs including crystal meth, crack cocaine and ketamine.

Grant Shapps, the Conservative chairman, called on Miliband and Ed Balls, the shadow chancellor, to "come clean on their relationship with Paul Flowers".

However, Michael Dugher, a senior Labour MP, said any inquiry should also examine the role of Mark Hoban, a former Treasury minister, who met Co-op around 30 times.

Flowers has told MPs on the Treasury committee that Hoban, a Tory finance minister, "encouraged" Co-op's plan to buy 630 branches from Lloyds in "many, many telephone conversations and meetings".

A review would also look at the appointment of Flowers, who had little financial experience, and struggled to answer basic questions about the bank's balance sheet during the hearing with MPs several weeks ago.

Downing Street sources later said that a decision on whether there should be an inquiry was expected "relatively soon".

Among the options being discussed with regulators by Osborne was a new power introduced last year for the chancellor to establish an independently-led inquiry.

A senior Labour source said that the government had questions to answer about reports of 30 meetings with the Co-op at a time when it was being encouraged to take over Lloyds branches. He described Cameron's inquiry suggestion as "a rather desperate political distraction".

Asked whether Labour would back an inquiry, he replied: "It depends what the inquiry is into."

The Labour source added: "I am not saying that there needs to be an inquiry. I am saying that there are questions to be answered."
