None of the investigations into the near collapse of banks during the 2008 crisis have been independent. The City regulator at the time, the Financial Services Authority, launched its own review into what went wrong at Royal Bank of Scotland, while publication of a review into why HBOS collapsed has yet to be published more than five years after the bank was rescued by Lloyds Banking Group. The coalition could task the new regulatory bodies to conduct an inquiry into the collapse of the Co-op and appoint an individual to oversee any inquiry. A decision is yet to be made on what form any inquiry could take. In the Commons Cameron put pressure on Miliband over Labour's links with the Co-op Bank after it emerged that donations and loans of more than £1m from the struggling financial institution had increased under Flowers's chairmanship. "What we can now see is that this bank, driven into the wall by this chairman, has been giving soft loans to the Labour party, facilities to the Labour party, donations to the Labour party, trooped in and out of Downing Street under Labour, still advising the leader of the Labour party," he said. "And yet, now we know, all along they knew about his past. Why did they do nothing to bring to the attention of the authorities this man who has broken a bank?" Police have searched the home of Flowers, a Methodist minister who led the bank for three years, after he was filmed allegedly buying and using hard drugs including crystal meth, crack cocaine and ketamine. Grant Shapps, the Conservative chairman, called on Miliband and Ed Balls, the shadow chancellor, to "come clean on their relationship with Paul Flowers". However, Michael Dugher, a senior Labour MP, said any inquiry should also examine the role of Mark Hoban, a former Treasury minister, who met Co-op around 30 times. Flowers has told MPs on the Treasury committee that Hoban, a Tory finance minister, "encouraged" Co-op's plan to buy 630 branches from Lloyds in "many, many telephone conversations and meetings". A review would also look at the appointment of Flowers, who had little financial experience, and struggled to answer basic questions about the bank's balance sheet during the hearing with MPs several weeks ago. Downing Street sources later said that a decision on whether there should be an inquiry was expected "relatively soon". Among the options being discussed with regulators by Osborne was a new power introduced last year for the chancellor to establish an independently-led inquiry. A senior Labour source said that the government had questions to answer about reports of 30 meetings with the Co-op at a time when it was being encouraged to take over Lloyds branches. He described Cameron's inquiry suggestion as "a rather desperate political distraction". Asked whether Labour would back an inquiry, he replied: "It depends what the inquiry is into." The Labour source added: "I am not saying that there needs to be an inquiry. I am saying that there are questions to be answered."

webTitle: Dixons impresses analysts with new Currys PC World format

fields.standfirst: Company visit ahead of interim figures receives positive comments
fields.body:
Dixons Retail has impressed analysts after showing off its new Currys PC World store, but investors are less enthused.

The company's shares have dipped 0.01p to 48.39p despite a positive reception to a visit to Aylesbury to see its new format. Analyst Nick Bubb said:

After all the recent focus on what Dixons has done to tidy up the loss-making peripheral European businesses, it was good to hear Dixons focus back on the outlook for the core UK operation yesterday morning and the analyst and investor trip to sunny Aylesbury to look at the new Currys PC World store was well attended.
Despite the very high ceiling, the merchandising in the store is all very low-level, to help with sight lines across the store for customers and staff, which means, for example, that the TV back-wall is less impressive than usual. But the emphasis is on the so-called "customer journeys", with simple messages and signs to help focus on what products people really want: it was good to see that the TV department focuses on things like screen size rather than trying to flog customers stupid cables. The white goods area focuses on innovation and there is a prominent department for "Floorcare", with steam cleaners the latest big thing (the Lakeside superstore is to get a new-look White Goods and Small Appliance department in January. The PC department is interesting, as the play tables are much smaller, to help the staff and customers get close to the product, and the focus is on Microsoft and Windows rather than on Apple (albeit the Fulham megastore has just had new Apple shop-in-shop refit). There were also demonstrations of the impressive data analytics now available to Dixons from its rapidly growing website traffic and of the all the new services available under the KnowHow brand. There was no current trading update, with the interims on 17 December not far away, but the impression given was that market share continues to improve and that management have plenty of ideas on how to keep pushing the business forward.

In a buy note Oriel Securities analyst Alistair Davies said momentum in the UK was strong, with the business on track to move into the 3% to 4% margin area. He said:

Dixons' analyst trip highlighted the company's continued steps in establishing itself in the UK as a service-led multichannel retailer.

Dixons' first half will reflect on a successful period following agreements to dispose of non-core assets. We forecast underlying group earnings before interest and tax of £39.4m (first half 2013 £8.8m) and underlying pretax profit of £9.4m (first half 2013 loss of £22.3m).
In the UK we expect second quarter like for like sales to have accelerated to 10%...An update in the coming year on the expiring Phones 4U contract could be a further positive. We continue to believe there is upside to forecasts within the UK business and reiterate our buy stance.

webTitle: GlaxoSmithKline raises £425m in South African share sale

fields.standfirst: UK pharmaceutical group disposes of part of its stake in Aspen Pharmacare
fields.body:
GlaxoSmithKline has moved higher after raising £425m by selling part of its stake in South African drugmaker Aspen Pharmacare.

Glaxo disposed of 28.2m shares in Aspen, leaving it with 12.4% of the business. It will retain a seat on the board of the business and has agreed not to sell any further shares for at least six months. Glaxo's head of strategy David Redfern said ahead of the completion of the sale:

Glaxo has a long and successful partnership with Aspen - and our investment in the company has grown in value significantly over time.
Having assessed this investment we have now decided to realise some of this value without altering the basis of the partnership.

Glaxo shares are currently 8.5p better at 1636.5p.

webTitle: 'Dovish' Bank of England minutes lessen chances of early interest rate rise

fields.bodyText: Prospects of any early rise in interest rates are receding after the Bank of England revealed that it would be some time before it even debated whether to increase the cost of borrowing. Revealing the thinking behind the decision to leave policy unchanged at its meeting earlier this month, Threadneedle Street's monetary policy committee said inflation had fallen more quickly than anticipated and there was no immediate threat to the economy from cost pressures. Minutes of the November meeting show that all nine MPC members agreed to keep official interest rates at 0.5% and to maintain the stock of government bonds bought under the Bank's quantitative easing programme at £375bn. Although the Bank is expecting the economy to grow by 0.9% in the final three months of 2013, the MPC is unsure both about the durability of the recovery and the extent to which growth in the economy's supply capacity will keep pace with rising demand for goods and services. In August, the Bank provided forward guidance in which it said it would not consider raising interest rates before unemployment fell to 7% – unless there was a threat from inflation or a housing bubble. The latest set of labour market data showed the jobless rate falling to 7.6%. The minutes admit that the Bank's projections showing inflation falling next year as output returns to its pre-recession levels are likely to be wrong, but add that provided there are no signs of an inflationary mentality becoming embedded there could be a case for not raising interest rates even when unemployment reaches the 7% threshold. "Once unemployment had reached 7%, the committee would reassess what it had learned about the nature of the recovery", the minutes say. Jonathan Loynes, chief European economist at Capital Economics, said the minutes "arguably strike a quite dovish tone in expressing 'uncertainty over the durability of the recovery' and suggesting that the slack in the economy will be 'eroded only gradually'."

webTitle: Internet shopping popularity boosts UK Mail profits

fields.standfirst: Six-month pre-tax profits were up 63% at post company as parcel volumes grew by 25%
fields.body:
Post and parcels company UK Mail has reported bumper profits as the rise in internet shopping pushes up demand for home delivery.

The Slough-based firm, which is one of Royal Mail's largest customers, announced a 63% growth in pre-tax profits to £12m for the six months to the end of September.

UK Mail's chief executive, Guy Buswell, said the company had seen parcel volumes increase by 25%. Speaking on BBC News, he said: "The parcels market is set to grow tremendously. By 2018, 22% of everything we buy other than food will be bought online."

The results came as the Royal Mail sell-off was under the spotlight again as senior bankers appeared before MPs over allegations that the 500-year old postal service was sold on the cheap.

The parcels that UK Mail collects from its business customers are given to Royal Mail for final delivery. Buswell said he was keen for Royal Mail to be more efficient and reduce its prices. "The privatisation will definitely make them more mean, more efficient and that is what we need."

While UK Mail's parcel revenues were up 21%, mail revenues dipped by 0.3%, which shows the changing nature of the postal business in the internet age. Revenues in its courier business, providing same-day delivery, fell by 4.4%, while its pallets delivery service for goods was down 1.6%.

UK Mail shares rose almost 6% in early trading to 35p.

webTitle: David Murray to head review of Australia’s financial system

fields.standfirst: The former chief executive of Commonwealth Bank will aim to increase competition and reduce regulation
fields.body:
David Murray, the former head of the future fund and former chief executive of the Commonwealth Bank, has been appointed to head the Abbott government’s “root and branch” review of Australia’s financial system.

Sixteen years after the last review of Australia’s banking system, which reported to former treasurer Peter Costello in 1997, the inquiry will aim to increase competition and reduce regulation.

The inquiry will look at Australia’s capacity to fund its growing economy and minimise its exposure to global financial markets, how to balance competition with stability and consumer protection and shifts in international financial regulation.

In a speech to the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry on Wednesday night, prime minister Tony Abbott said Murray would head a committee of “four eminent Australians drawn from the finance, business and academic sectors” and would “draw on a special external council comprising five international business people to specifically advise on matters relating to international competitiveness and offshore regulatory frameworks and related issues”.

The final details for the inquiry will be announced in mid-December. It will publish an interim report by September 2014 and a final report by November 2014.

webTitle: FTSE 100 slips back ahead of central banks' minutes

fields.standfirst: Vodafone leads fallers as mobile phone group's shares go ex-dividend
fields.body:
Markets are drifting lower ahead of some key US data and the latest Federal Reserve and Bank of England minutes.

A number of companies going ex-dividend also is also having a negative effect on the leading index. So the FTSE 100 is down 10.35 points at 6687.66, with Vodafone among the biggest fallers. The mobile phone group - tipped this week once more as a bid target - is down 4.3p to 227.75p as its shares were quoted without the shareholder payout. Ishaq Siddiqi, market strategist at ETX Capital, said:

There is a soft start to the European trading session as the market awaits high profile US economic data and the Fed's meeting minutes from the October policy meeting for more clues over the health of the world's largest economy.
Overnight, we had a mixed session in Asian markets with Chinese indices still supported by the country's reform plans announced in the past few days. Japan's share market dropped however as trade data suggested the weaker yen over the past year was the reason for the widening in the trade deficit. In the US on Tuesday, Fed chairman Ben Bernanke emphasised that any tapering of QE will be data-dependent but did not drop any hints on when the Bank will initiate tapering. The market viewed his reluctance to change his rhetoric as a sign that we could still be facing the prospects of tapering as early as next month.

Aberdeen Asset Management moved higher in the wake of this week's £660m acquisition of Scottish Widows from Lloyds Banking Group. It has added 13.5p to 488.7p as Barclays and Berenberg both raised their price targets.

EasyJet has jumped another 20p to £13.65 after its well received results.

But drinks group Diageo has dipped 20p to 2008.5p after an investor day on Tuesday, in which it moved away from its previous stance of giving forward guidance. Mike Dennis at Cantor Fitzgerald said:

Our overall take was that the outlook was for less top-line sales growth (below the 5%-8% net sales growth range and more price than volume) and less margin gains versus 2012 and 2013. Diageo is facing less predictable growth patterns in Emerging Markets as GDP growth rates slow and, sales of their largest spirit brand, Smirnoff Vodka, slow too. Hence Diageo is becoming more reliant on taking price, introducing premium brands into new acquisition markets (Turkey, India) and improving logistics to offset lower US growth (US is 33% of group, around 50% of profit). Diageo continues to see the need for promotional and advertising spend at 15.5% of sales.
Management has indicated that they are not giving more forward guidance on sales and margin accretion but expect to achieve the current three year operating margin gain of 200 basis points by June 2014. The indication is that cash is first needed to reinvest in the business to secure existing return on investment and then used for selective small emerging market bolt on acquisitions and future buy-backs. On the positive side, Diageo has a scale advantage, a very broad product portfolio, another year of 60 plus product innovations and a cash re-investment rate higher than its competitors. However, Diageo also needs to show that the £3bn spent on 8 acquisitions in emerging markets will make planned returns over the next three years. Five of these Emerging Market deals are only owned 51% or less so maybe Diageo will use any excess cash flow to first secure 100% of the future potential upside in existing investments before any new brands are added. Diageo also faces issues in China with the government clamp down on excessive gifting, as well as tighter regulations on alcohol consumption in Turkey. The share price performance largely reflects these issues. The 2014 estimated 17.5 times enterprise value/EBIT multiple is now close to the sector average in the packaged goods and beverages sector albeit first half results due at the end of January 2014 may disappoint, similar to the first quarter with organic net sales growth of 3.1%.

Building materials group Wolseley, which has a strong presence in the US, has slipped 12p to £32.38 after the American Institute of Architects' Architecture Billings Index fell to 51.6 in October after hitting a seven-month high of 54.3 in September.

webTitle: JP Morgan Chase agrees record $13bn settlement charges over toxic mortgages

fields.bodyText: JP Morgan Chase, the biggest bank in the United States, agreed a record $13bn (£8bn) settlement with regulators on Tuesday, ending months of tense negotiations with the Justice Department over a string of investigations into its risky mortgage deals. The fine, the biggest civil settlement with any single company, ends several investigations and lawsuits brought by the US authorities related to the sale of home loan bonds between 2005 and 2008. It is more than three times the previous record $4bn fine the US levied against BP for the Deepwater Horizon oil spill. Settlement talks have been fraught and lengthy. JP Morgan chief executive Jamie Dimon went to the US Justice Department to personally negotiate with attorney general Eric Holder in September, a personal summit that led some critics to claim that Holder was giving the bank special treatment. Tuesday’s agreement staves off a costly and potentially embarrassing trial. As part of the settlement, JP Morgan acknowledged it made serious misrepresentations to the public – including to investors – about numerous transactions relating to residential mortgage-backed securities. The deals collapsed in 2008 when the housing market plunged and the scale of the risks was exposed, and the resulting financial tumult led to the biggest crisis since the Great Depression. The admission was a major victory for the Justice Department. Banks have fought shy of such statements fearing yet more legal actions from investors. The settlement leaves open the possibility of potential criminal charges. “Without a doubt, the conduct uncovered in this investigation helped sow the seeds of the mortgage meltdown,” said Holder. “JP Morgan was not the only financial institution during this period to knowingly bundle toxic loans and sell them to unsuspecting investors, but that is no excuse for the firm’s behavior.” “The size and scope of this resolution should send a clear signal that the Justice Department’s financial fraud investigations are far from over. No firm, no matter how profitable, is above the law, and the passage of time is no shield from accountability,” Holder said. The settlement was negotiated through the residential mortgage-backed securities (RMBS) working group, a joint state and federal initiative formed in 2012 to investigate wrongdoing in the mortgage-backed securities market prior to the financial crisis. Holder said the group’s investigations were “ongoing”. John Coffee, a Columbia law school professor, said the fine was in marked contrast to the $1.9bn penalty Holder brought against HSBC for money laundering last December. “In that case he seemed to suggest some institutions were ‘too big to jail’,” said Coffee. In this case, Coffee said, Holder was still looking to bring charges against individuals in the future. Coffee said the US authorities had so far struggled to charge senior individuals over the excesses of the financial crisis. “But the government is still looking. We may yet see another shoe drop,” he said. JP Morgan sailed through the financial crisis relatively unharmed, but has been beset by legal woes in the crisis's aftermath. The fine is the latest, and largest, in a series that has led for some shareholders to call for Dimon’s resignation despite the bank's financial success and its solid share price: • Earlier this month, the bank paid $4.5bn to settle allegations it has mis-sold mortgage bonds to pension funds and other institutional investors. • In September, the company paid $920m to settle US investigations into the “London Whale” trading scandal. • In the same month, JP Morgan paid another $390m in refunds and $80m in settlement for billing credit card customers for identity theft protection they did not receive. • In July, the bank paid $410m in penalties and repayments related to alleged manipulation of California and midwest electricity markets. The latest fine stems in large part from allegations of mis-selling of “toxic” mortgage securities by Bear Stearns and Washington Mutual, two firms JP Morgan purchased during the 2008 financial crisis at the behest of the government. Of the $13bn resolution, $9bn will be paid to settle federal and state civil claims by various entities related to RMBS. The heavily trailed agreement appears to have been delayed by arguments over the consumer-relief component of the pact that constitutes the remaining $4bn of the deal. That money will be used to reduce urban blight in areas such as Detroit, where the sub-prime crisis worsened an already struggling housing market and left many homes abandoned. They money will also be used to offer lower rate loans to low-income home buyers. About $1.4bn will go to the National Credit Union Administration. “Today’s announcement by the Justice Department is extraordinary, and will greatly benefit credit unions that have been paying for the losses caused by the financial institutions covered by this settlement,” NCUA chairman Debbie Matz said. Brian Kettenring, executive director of the Campaign for a Fair Settlement, said the size of the settlement was a “show of progress toward holding banks accountable for repeatedly breaking the law.” “Criminal prosecution is still needed to deter future crimes. But more and likely better relief for struggling homeowners is a hard-earned victory for people across the country who have spoken out—and even gone to jail—demanding an end to Wall Street impunity,” he said. Deborah Castillo, a member of pressure group Home Defenders League who lost her home to foreclosure said: “JPMorgan Chase should halt foreclosures while the settlement is implemented and make a good faith work with the homeowners in our communities who need fair modifications. I hope that funds from this settlement will quickly get to homeowners, who have waited far too long for relief, and are really used to help the families who are struggling and prevent the crime of more empty houses in our communities.” While this agreement ends a troubled chapter for the bank, other issues remain. A criminal investigation of the bank over mortgages will continue. The bank is also under scrutiny for its hiring practices in China, its massive “London Whale” trading losses and its relationship with Bernie Madoff, the Ponzi scheme fraudster.

fields.headline: JP Morgan Chase agrees record $13bn settlement charges over toxic mortgages
fields.body:
JP Morgan Chase, the biggest bank in the United States, agreed a record $13bn (£8bn) settlement with regulators on Tuesday, ending months of tense negotiations with the Justice Department over a string of investigations into its risky mortgage deals.

The fine, the biggest civil settlement with any single company, ends several investigations and lawsuits brought by the US authorities related to the sale of home loan bonds between 2005 and 2008. It is more than three times the previous record $4bn fine the US levied against BP for the Deepwater Horizon oil spill.

Settlement talks have been fraught and lengthy. JP Morgan chief executive Jamie Dimon went to the US Justice Department to personally negotiate with attorney general Eric Holder in September, a personal summit that led some critics to claim that Holder was giving the bank special treatment. Tuesday’s agreement staves off a costly and potentially embarrassing trial.

As part of the settlement, JP Morgan acknowledged it made serious misrepresentations to the public – including to investors – about numerous transactions relating to residential mortgage-backed securities. The deals collapsed in 2008 when the housing market plunged and the scale of the risks was exposed, and the resulting financial tumult led to the biggest crisis since the Great Depression.

The admission was a major victory for the Justice Department. Banks have fought shy of such statements fearing yet more legal actions from investors. The settlement leaves open the possibility of potential criminal charges.

“Without a doubt, the conduct uncovered in this investigation helped sow the seeds of the mortgage meltdown,” said Holder. “JP Morgan was not the only financial institution during this period to knowingly bundle toxic loans and sell them to unsuspecting investors, but that is no excuse for the firm’s behavior.”

“The size and scope of this resolution should send a clear signal that the Justice Department’s financial fraud investigations are far from over. No firm, no matter how profitable, is above the law, and the passage of time is no shield from accountability,” Holder said.

The settlement was negotiated through the residential mortgage-backed securities (RMBS) working group, a joint state and federal initiative formed in 2012 to investigate wrongdoing in the mortgage-backed securities market prior to the financial crisis. Holder said the group’s investigations were “ongoing”.

John Coffee, a Columbia law school professor, said the fine was in marked contrast to the $1.9bn penalty Holder brought against HSBC for money laundering last December. “In that case he seemed to suggest some institutions were ‘too big to jail’,” said Coffee. In this case, Coffee said, Holder was still looking to bring charges against individuals in the future.

Coffee said the US authorities had so far struggled to charge senior individuals over the excesses of the financial crisis. “But the government is still looking. We may yet see another shoe drop,” he said.

JP Morgan sailed through the financial crisis relatively unharmed, but has been beset by legal woes in the crisis's aftermath. The fine is the latest, and largest, in a series that has led for some shareholders to call for Dimon’s resignation despite the bank's financial success and its solid share price:

• Earlier this month, the bank paid $4.5bn to settle allegations it has mis-sold mortgage bonds to pension funds and other institutional investors.

• In September, the company paid $920m to settle US investigations into the “London Whale” trading scandal.

• In the same month, JP Morgan paid another $390m in refunds and $80m in settlement for billing credit card customers for identity theft protection they did not receive.

• In July, the bank paid $410m in penalties and repayments related to alleged manipulation of California and midwest electricity markets.

The latest fine stems in large part from allegations of mis-selling of “toxic” mortgage securities by Bear Stearns and Washington Mutual, two firms JP Morgan purchased during the 2008 financial crisis at the behest of the government.

Of the $13bn resolution, $9bn will be paid to settle federal and state civil claims by various entities related to RMBS.

The heavily trailed agreement appears to have been delayed by arguments over the consumer-relief component of the pact that constitutes the remaining $4bn of the deal. That money will be used to reduce urban blight in areas such as Detroit, where the sub-prime crisis worsened an already struggling housing market and left many homes abandoned. They money will also be used to offer lower rate loans to low-income home buyers.

About $1.4bn will go to the National Credit Union Administration. “Today’s announcement by the Justice Department is extraordinary, and will greatly benefit credit unions that have been paying for the losses caused by the financial institutions covered by this settlement,” NCUA chairman Debbie Matz said.

Brian Kettenring, executive director of the Campaign for a Fair Settlement, said the size of the settlement was a “show of progress toward holding banks accountable for repeatedly breaking the law.”

“Criminal prosecution is still needed to deter future crimes. But more and likely better relief for struggling homeowners is a hard-earned victory for people across the country who have spoken out—and even gone to jail—demanding an end to Wall Street impunity,” he said.

Deborah Castillo, a member of pressure group Home Defenders League who lost her home to foreclosure said: “JPMorgan Chase should halt foreclosures while the settlement is implemented and make a good faith work with the homeowners in our communities who need fair modifications. I hope that funds from this settlement will quickly get to homeowners, who have waited far too long for relief, and are really used to help the families who are struggling and prevent the crime of more empty houses in our communities.”

While this agreement ends a troubled chapter for the bank, other issues remain. A criminal investigation of the bank over mortgages will continue. The bank is also under scrutiny for its hiring practices in China, its massive “London Whale” trading losses and its relationship with Bernie Madoff, the Ponzi scheme fraudster.

webTitle: Asda puts shopping collection points in tube station car parks

fields.standfirst: Pilot scheme with Transport for London will allow shoppers who order before midday to pick up groceries after 4pm
fields.body:
London commuters will be able to pick up groceries ordered online on the way home from work as Asda puts collection points in six tube station car parks.

The partnership with the London underground operator Transport for London will enable shoppers to order the goods online before 12 noon and pick them up after 4pm. The scheme is part of Asda's plans to add 1,000 more places where shoppers can pick up online orders and extend its operations in London and the south-east of England.

"Customers in the south-east tell us they want the prices and quality provided by Asda value, but they can't access it easily. This tie-up with TfL solves that,"said Asda's retail director, Mark Ibbotson.

If the scheme proves successful at the six pilot locations – East Finchley, Harrow and Wealdstone, High Barnet, Highgate, Stanmore and Epping – Asda intends to expand to more tube station pick-up points.
